Texto: The US-China trade beef is turning up the heat on the meat sector.After the two economies traded tit-for-tat tariff plans, US meat producers were trudging higher on a fall in the price of soyabeans, one of the grains used to fatten up livestock destined for slaughter (China has targeted US exports of the crop for potential retaliatory tariffs.)•Hormel shares are up 4.9 per cent to $35.91•Pilgrim’s Pride is up 2.5 per cent to $24.72•Tyson Foods shares up 2.24 per cent to $71.50•Sanderson Farms shares up 1.4 per cent to $119.30On the flip side, cattle futures were sliding lower as China took aim at US beef exports as well.CME live cattle futures were down 1.45 per cent to $110.35, briefly touching $110.10 earlier in the session, their lowest point since October, according to Thomson Reuters data.

Titular: China pork duties give US meat producers a roasting
Texto: It’s not just technology stocks that are getting pummeled on Monday.Shares in leading US meat processors are also feeling the market’s ire, with investors fleeing the sector after China raised tariffs on imports of American pork products to 25 per cent in retaliation against President Donald Trump’s steel and aluminium tariffs.Tyson Foods, the country’s biggest meat producer by market value, fell as much as 6.3 per cent to $68.56. The decline marks the stock’s biggest one-day drop in nearly 11 months and takes the shares to their lowest level in over six months.Hormel Foods, the maker of Spam, dropped 2.6 per cent to $33.43 while smaller players such as Pilgrim’s Pride and Sanderson Farms were down 1.4 per cent at $24.26 and 1.1 per cent to $117.73 respectively.Tim Ramey, analyst at Pivotal Research Group, said in a report on Monday that in the medium term, it would be very difficult for meat producers to change the course of production meaningfully to adjust for external shocks such as the China tariffs.“We expect the Chinese tariff to cause meat supplies in the US to back up meaningfully as the market has to be cleared,” he said in the report.Alongside pork, Beijing also imposed or raised tariffs on 127 other US products — including a variety of fruits, nuts and wine — in a blow to American farmers given that China is the second-biggest customer for US agricultural exports after Canada.Commodities traders Archer Daniels Midland and Bunge also fell amid a broader markets sell off, with both companies shedding 2.2 per cent.(Photo: Reuters)

Titular: Tyson Foods weighs sale of pizza crust business
Texto: Tyson Foods is considering slicing off a “pizza” its food business as it focuses in on its key protein offerings.Tyson, one of the world’s largest food companies, said on Tuesday evening it had hired Goldman Sachs to help it explore a sale of its pizza crust business, TNT Crust, which offers partly baked, flat bread and self-rising crusts, as well as two plants in Green Bay, Wisconsin.Tyson intends to hold on to its tortilla production from those facilities, it said. Sally Grimes, group president of Tyson prepared foods, said in a statement:“We’re focused on maximising the full potential of our core business, and this divestiture will help pave the way for growth in our protein brands. We believe a potential buyer will see the value of the pizza crust business as a whole, including the TNT Crust brand, the facilities, and the talented team members, and will be able to focus on its future.”While revenue from its pizza crust business was not broken out in its latest annual report, it is part of the company’s prepared foods segment, which pulled in $7.8bn in revenue altogether in 2017, according to its annual report.Tyson shares, which were up 31.4 per cent in 2017, are down nearly 9 per cent thus far in 2018. They advanced 0.55 per cent in after-hours trading.

Titular: Tyson profits beefed up by strong global meat demand
Subtitular: ‘Demand for protein continues to rise, and we’re well-positioned’
Texto: America’s love affair with meat helped Tyson Foods blow past expectations for its fiscal first-quarter results.The meat giant, which sold more than $30bn worth of beef, chicken and pork last year, saw its shares climb more than 4 per cent in pre-market trading on Thursday as it also raised its earnings guidance for the year.Sales for the last three months of 2017 came in at $10.2bn, a 11.4 per cent rise from the prior year period and ahead of forecasts of $9.9bn.The sales gains were driven by demand for products across its four main divisions. Growth at its beef, pork, chicken and prepared food units were boosted by stronger consumer spending in the US, better pricing power, and increased exports.“Demand for protein continues to rise, and we’re well-positioned to take advantage of that opportunity,” said Tom Hayes, chief executive.Net income attributable to the company surged to $1.63bn, or $4.40 per diluted share, from $594m, or $1.59 a share, a year ago. The jump was largely because of savings stemming from the recent changes to US corporate tax rates. Stripping those out, adjusted earnings were $1.81, still easily topping estimates for $1.50 a share.Tyson said as a result of the expected tax gains, it now forecasts full year adjusted earnings of between $6.55-$6.70 a share, up from previous guidance of $5.70-$5.85 and sharply higher than the $5.31 reported in 2017. Sales for the fiscal year are expected to grow between 6 and 7 per cent to $41bn.The Arkansas-based meat processor also said it planned to pay its workforce more than $100m in cash bonuses as a result of the tax gains.The stock, up 12.2 per cent over the past 12 months, gained 4.2 per cent in pre-market trade.

Titular: Chicken suppliers clipped by latest antitrust claims
Texto: Major US chicken suppliers including Tyson Foods and Pilgrim’s Pride are seeing investors fly the coop on Wednesday after two major US food distributors became the latest to accuse them of participating in a years-long conspiracy to reduce the supply and raise prices for chickens.Shares of Arkansas-based Tyson Foods were down 4.36 per cent to $75.45, heading for their biggest one-day drop since May, while Pilgrim’s Pride, headquartered in Colorado, dropped 3.8 per cent to $28.49.The declines come after the Wall Street Journal reported that US Foods and Sysco – two major US food distributors – became the latest to serve up allegations of anti-competitive in the market for broiler chickens, which account for nearly all of the chicken meat sold in the US, in lawsuits filed Tuesday in federal court in Illinois.The claims echo those brought in recent civil litigation by distributors and farmers and other purchasers accusing the major US chicken producers of colluding for years to drive prices higher, including through alleged manipulation of the Georgia Dock, a widely used index for wholesale chickens that was subsequently suspended.Tyson has previously disclosed that it was being investigated by Florida’s attorney general in connection with the allegations. A probe by the US Securities and Exchange Commission ended without any recommendation of an enforcement action against Tyson, the company disclosed in a letter last year.A Tyson spokesman said in a statement: “Follow-on complaints like these are common in antitrust litigation. Such complaints do not change our position that the claims are unfounded. We will continue to vigorously defend our company.”A Pilgrim’s spokesman said: “Pilgrim’s believes the case is completely without merit. We look forward to defending our interests through the appropriate legal process.”Photo source: Getty Images

Titular: Tyson tops estimates on strong global meat demand
Texto: Freer-spending Americans and strong demand for meat from a growing global middle class helped Tyson Foods deliver another set of forecast-busting results for its fiscal fourth quarter.Shares in the US meat processor jumped 3 per cent in pre-market trading as investors cheered a 10.8 per cent rise in sales to $10.1bn and a near 50 per cent jump in adjusted net income.Tyson notched sales gains across its four main divisions in the three months to the end of September. Growth at its beef, pork, chicken and prepared food units were boosted by stronger consumer spending in the US and increased exports. Margins were further helped by higher meat supplies and lower prices for animal feed.“The fourth quarter was a strong finish to another record year,” said chief executive Tom Hayes.Although sales rose sharply during the quarter, net profit was largely flat at $391m due to costs related to its $3.2bn acquisition of packaged sandwich supplier AdvancePierre Foods earlier this year. Stripping this out, adjusted net income came in at $1.43 a share compared to the 96 cents recorded in the prior year period. Analysts had expected $1.36 a share on revenue of $9.9bn.The company also issued an upbeat outlook for the 2018 fiscal year. It is projecting sales to increase another 7 per cent to $41bn. The figure excludes revenue of the three non-protein businesses (Sara Lee Frozen Bakery, Kettle and Van’s) that it is selling.Shares in Tyson, up by more than a fifth so far this year, rose 3.1 per cent ahead of the bell. The gain puts the stock, which closed at $74.14 on Friday, one step closer to surpassing the record high of $77.05 reached last year.

Titular: Tyson Foods beefs up guidance, shares jump
Texto: A renewed appetite for beef among American consumers has prompted meat producer Tyson Foods to lift its full-year earnings guidance, sending the company’s shares sharply higher in post-market trading on Thursday.Shares in Tyson, up 6 per cent so far this year, jumped another 6 per cent in after-hours trading as investors cheered the surprise rise in profits outlook.The company said it now expects adjusted earnings for the fiscal 2017 year, which ends this Saturday, to come in between $5.20-$5.30 per share, up from its previous prediction of $4.95-$5.05 per share.Arkansas-based Tyson attributed the revision primarily to “much better than expected earnings” in its beef business. The unit is the company’s biggest and generated 37 per cent of total group revenue and 24 per cent of group operating profit last year.As a result of the beef division’s outperformance, Tyson said it now sees adjusted earnings for the fiscal 2018 year between $5.70-$5.85, compared to the consensus guidance of $5.34 per share.Tyson, which is due to report its fiscal fourth quarter results on November 13, also outlined plans to cut 450 jobs across the group as it pushes ahead with previously announced plans to restructure its businesses.As a result of the restructuring, the company said it expects to take a one of charge of $140m-$150m in the fourth quarter.

Titular: Tyson Foods says SEC closes chicken-pricing investigation
Texto: No fowl play.Tyson Foods shares nosed slightly higher on Friday morning after it said that US securities regulators had ended an investigation of the company related to allegations that it engaged in anti-competitive behaviour in the chicken market.The Arkansas-headquartered company — the largest producer of poultry in the US — said in a statement that it had received a letter from the US Securities and Exchange Commission on August 22 regarding the agency’s previously announced probe.“The letter stated that the SEC staff has concluded its investigation and that, based on the information it has as of that date, it does not intend to recommend an enforcement action by the SEC against Tyson,” Tyson said in a statement.Tyson shares have been weighed down in recent months by investigations sparked by civil litigation accusing the company and others in the poultry industry of colluding for years to drive prices higher. The company had previously said that it was cooperating with the SEC after receiving a subpoena on January 20 regarding the probe, which it believed was linked to the litigation.Allegations related to the Georgia Dock chicken products pricing index formerly published by the Georgia Department of Agriculture are also being investigated by Florida’s attorney general, Tyson has previously disclosed.Tyson shares were up 0.5 per cent in early trading on Friday.

Titular: Consumer staples set to be only sector to eke out weekly gain on S&P 500
Texto: US stocks are poised for their biggest one-week sell-off since March, and consumer staples might be the only sector to eke out a gain when markets close on Friday.Heightened tensions with North Korea dominated headlines this week, weighing on investors’ risk appetite and prompting a broad-based decline in US stocks.A slate of disappointing earnings from department stores helped drag consumer discretionary stocks lower, while concerns about valuation alongside the risk-off sentiment weighed on the technology sector. However, energy led the decline, falling 2.7 per cent over the week as West Texas Intermediate, the US crude marker, dropped 1.7 per cent over the past five days.Consumer staples, however, rose 0.3 per cent over the week. The sector was led by Tyson Foods, which climbed 4 per cent over the week after the company forecast higher sales and said pork exports should boost its margins.

Titular: Tyson Foods climbs after summer barbecue weather
Subtitular: US stock volatility levels drop to five-decade low
Texto: Tyson Foods investors have the summer weather to thank for a jump in their shares as Americans fired up their barbecues.Increased appetite at home and abroad for its beef and pork products bolstered sales and prompted the Arizona-headquartered food company to nudge its full-year profit forecast higher.Tom Hayes, chief executive, hailed a “strong start for the grilling season” for the upgrade, among other reasons.For the three months ending July 1, Tyson reported net sales of $9.85bn, above the $9.46bn analysts surveyed by Bloomberg had expected. Net income came in at $447m, versus the $437.9m Wall Street was looking for.Mr Hayes said sales for the quarter were 4.8 per cent higher, year-on-year, as “every segment delivered volume growth behind a strong start to grilling season and new product innovation.”The company attributed its increased revenue to increased domestic demand, strong exports and lower livestock costs.Chicken volumes also improved, albeit it at a slower rate than beef and pork. Some of the gains were partly offset by disruptions caused by fires at two of its plants.Tyson shares, which had sagged 14 per cent over the past 12 months, closed up 5.7 per cent at $66.90 on Monday in New York.The overall market was also positive: the S&P 500 rose 0.2 per cent to 2,480.91 and the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.5 per cent to 6,383.77 — continuing the steady moves higher that have characterised the latest leg of the bull run.In fact, the last time the US stock market was this becalmed, Richard Nixon was sitting in the White House and Sly & The Family Stone topped the US singles charts.The 10-day rolling volatility of the S&P 500 dipped to a five-decade low of just 2.43 per cent early on Monday — the lowest since February 14, 1969 — as the remarkable tranquility of markets this year is exacerbated by the traditional summer trading lull. It rose later, ending the day at 2.57 per cent.The CBOE Vix index of the short-term expected volatility implied by US option prices also dipped below 10 again.Elsewhere, Tesla is set to test investor demand for riskier corporate bonds as it readies to borrow $1.5bn through debt markets later this week.The sale, announced on Monday, would be the first from the electric carmaker in the high-yield corporate bond market and would be used to “strengthen” its balance sheet as it launches its newest vehicle, the Model 3.Its shares were down 0.5 per cent at $355.17 on the day.The company run by billionaire Elon Musk has traditionally issued convertible bonds or raised capital through equity markets, including nearly $4.5bn over the past three years according to Dealogic data.Tesla shares have advanced 66 per cent this year, giving the company a market valuation of roughly $60bn, above General Motors and Ford.Convertible bonds sold earlier this year from Tesla, that mature in 2022, have fallen 3 per cent from a June high, although they are up more than 25 per cent this year, according to fixed income trading platform MarketAxess.Twitter: @ericgplatt

Titular: ‘Strong start to grilling season’: Beef and pork bolster Tyson Foods sales
Texto: Increased appetites at home and abroad for its beef and pork products bolstered Tyson Foods’ sales and prompted the US-based food company to nudge higher its full-year profit forecast.For the three months ending July 1, Tyson reported net sales of $9.85bn, above the $9.46bn analysts surveyed by Bloomberg had expected.Tyson chief executive Tom Hayes noted that sales for the quarter were 4.8 per cent higher year-on-year, as “every segment delivered volume growth behind a strong start to grilling season and new product innovation”.It attributed its increased revenue to rising sales volumes in its beef and pork segments, thanks to increased domestic demand, strong exports and lower livestock costs. Chicken volumes also improved, albeit it at a slower rate, with some of those gains partly offset by disruptions caused by fires at two of its plants, among other factors, the company said.Net income attributable to the company came in at $447m, versus the $437.87m Wall Street was looking for, coming to $1.21 a share, compared to expectations for $1.18. Adjusted for special items, earnings per share were $1.28.The better-than-expected results prompted Tyson to lift its full-year profit outlook. It is now looking for adjusted earnings per share of $4.95-$5.05 for fiscal 2017, a 13 per cent increased year-on-year, adding to the lower end of its previous guidance for earnings between $4.90 and $5.05.It is also looking for full-year sales to top $38bn as sales volume expands across categories, with a target of $41bn in revenue for full-year 2018.Tyson shares, which have sagged 14 per cent over the past 12 months, were up 2.5 per cent in pre-market trading.

Titular: Greencore shares surge as Peacock lifts sales
Subtitular: UK’s biggest sandwich maker rises 8% after sales jump on back of US acquisition
Texto: Greencore, the UK’s biggest sandwich maker, has reported a 46 per cent jump in first-half sales, after a promising start to the group’s US expansion through last year’s $748m acquisition of Illinois-based Peacock Foods.Dublin-based Greencore said it expected annual sales to double between 2016 and 2018 to £3bn, thanks to Peacock and its own fast-expanding UK convenience food business, which registered a 16 per cent rise in sales in the six months to the end of March.Shares in the FTSE 250 group rose 8 per cent on Tuesday, recouping the 7 per cent one-day tumble they took last month on fears that Greencore could lose its most valuable customer Tyson Foods, after the US company bought AdvancePierre, a rival of Peacock.The shares are still 15 per cent down on a year ago after a volatile year punctuated by disappointing results when the group was making a push into the US by itself, before the Peacock acquisition.Regarding the relationship with Tyson, Patrick Coveney, Greencore chief executive, said: “We are comfortable and reassured about the prospects of us growing our business together, based on the set of initiatives we are working on together.”Greencore’s revenues of £1bn were 46 per cent higher than the same period last year, with £220m coming from Peacock since December, when the acquisition was completed.Peacock, which has annual revenues of $1bn, stands to quadruple Greencore’s US sales, which had been $300m before the acquisition.Group pre-tax profits dropped 44 per cent to £11.7m, mainly due to £22.9m of exceptional costs related to the acquisition, including fees and integration costs.Excluding these exceptionals, group operating profits rose 27 per cent year on year to £55.3m.Mr Coveney described 2017 as a “transition year” in which Greencore would integrate Peacock and work on delivering 20 per cent revenue growth in its UK food-to-go business of sandwiches and sushi. It is investing £100m in expanding production at some UK factories, after winning a number of new contracts.“You are seeing a high level of investment activity and change that’s been compressed into 2017,” said Mr Coveney.Darren Shirley, analyst at Shore Capital, said: “We believe the Peacock acquisition will transform the group’s long-term prospects in North America from a previously subscale position.”

Titular: Tyson bulks up ready food unit with $4.2bn AdvancePierre deal
Texto: It’s a deal made in processed food heaven.Tyson Foods, the US meat producer, is buying ready meal maker AdvancePierre Foods for $4.2bn, including debt.Tyson, which already owns Hillshire Brands, the maker of lunch meats and Ball Park hot dogs, is offering $40.25 cash per each AdvancePierre share – giving the company an equity value of about $3.2bn. In addition, Tyson will also assume about $1.1bn of AdvancePierre’s debt.The offer is 31.8 per cent premium to the target company’s unaffected share price. However, several traders noted to the FT that there was highly unusual trading activity in AdvancePierre shares in recent weeks.Oaktree Capital Management, which owns 42 per cent of AdvancePierre shares, has agreed to tender its holdings and support the deal.“The addition of AdvancePierre aligns with our strategic intent to sustainably feed the world with the fastest growing portfolio of protein packed brands,” said Tyson president and chief executive Tom Hayes.Tyson said it expects to cut approximately $200m in costs on an annual basis within three years of the deal closing.Ohio-based AdvancePierre makes ready to eat burgers and cold cut sandwiches for supermarkets, schools and convenience stores. The self-styled “leading national producer and distributor of value-added, convenient, ready-to-eat sandwiches, sandwich components” posted revenues of $1.6bn last year and employs about 4,500 people across the country.

Titular: Bird flu sickens shares in chicken producers
Texto: Shares in chicken producers were down on their cluck after a second case of the bird flu was confirmed in Tennessee.The chicken farms, which are affiliated with Tyson Foods, are located less than two miles away apart and have begun euthanizing its chickens to prevent a the potential spread of the disease.Shares in the company fell 2.5 per cent on Wednesday, prompting a slide rival chicken producers. Sanderson Farms fell 2.1 per cent, Pilgrim’s Pride lost 1.2 per cent and Hormel Foods, which makes processed chicken food products, retreated 1.2 per cent.The virus, which rarely infects humans, was reported earlier this month by the Tennessee Department of Agriculture, which has quarantined the area in Lincoln County. There are also reports of the virus in Alabama.Tyson said it was coordinating with the agriculture department and USDA on a quick response. All of its flocks are located within a six-mile radius of the original farm and will “not be transported unless they test negative for the virus”.“This a bird health issue and not a food safety or human health concern,” the company said in a statement. “We don’t expect disruptions to our chicken business and plan to meet our customers’ needs.”The outbreak was compounded by analyst downgrades on the day. Although Tyson posted strong first quarter results, investors have expressed concerns regarding an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission over alleged manipulation of a chicken pricing index.John Staszak, an Argus analyst, said there was a potential for decelerating earnings in the upcoming quarters and was concerned about recent bird flu outbreak.

Titular: Tyson Foods: poultry results
Subtitular: There are questions around chicken profits and alleged price collusion
Texto: Meat might take a smaller share of Americans’ future diets. Tyson Foods, the largest US traditional meat processor, is anxious to hedge its bets. In December it launched its own $150m venture capital fund to find novel protein sources. It has already invested in a plant-based start-up called, appropriately, Beyond Meat.This followed another big strategic move in 2014: paying $8bn to win a bidding war for Hillshire Brands, which provided an entry into higher-margin packaged foods. Despite the steep price, investors appreciated the synergies. And over five years, the bold approach has paid off. Tyson shares have risen 234 per cent.For the time being, however, cows, pigs and chickens are still crucial. On Monday, they contributed to a record first quarter, with quarterly earnings up 38 per cent. Poultry, though, continues to let the side down.In the previous quarter, weak results in the chicken segment dragged down the earnings. The company attributed the margin shortfall to higher soyabean prices and one-time operational issues. The latest quarter brought more fowl results: another profit margin decline blamed this time on higher marketing expense. Still, Tyson’s beef and pork segments both hit record margins.If it were just chickens to blame, Tyson investors could be more sanguine but there are other clouds. In November, Tyson replaced its long-time chief executive. It also said it would spend $1bn in capital expenditures this year with the pay-off likely lower than operating costs.On Monday Tyson said that the Securities and Exchange Commission was probing what is thought to be the company’s role in an alleged chicken price collusion scheme (separate civil litigation is ongoing). Tyson was confident enough to boost its profit forecast for the fiscal year. But the litigation uncertainty sent the shares down another couple of points and they are now 18 per cent down from their October high.Tyson is thinking about the future of food. But investors remain preoccupied with the company’s past.Email the Lex team at lex@ft.com

Titular: Tyson falls amid SEC scrutiny over chicken-pricing suits
Texto: Chicken-gate?Shares in Tyson Foods are in retreat on Monday after the US’s largest meat processor said it received an inquiry last month from US securities regulators, which it said is likely connected to a civil litigation accusing it and other companies of conspiring to fix broiler chicken prices.The Arkansas-company, the biggest player in the US for so-called broiler chicken – or birds raised specifically for meat production – said in a regulatory filing that it had been served a subpoena on January 20 from the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with an investigation related to the company. It said the allegations were likely similar to those in recent civil litigation that accused it of working with other meat processors to coordinate output, limit production and share sensitive information in order to boost chicken prices, claims that defendants have denied.“We are cooperating with the investigation, which is at an early stage,” the company said in the filing.Shares in the company fell 2 per cent to $64.10 in early trading in New York.Tyson and other poultry producers have faced a number of civil lawsuits over the past few months from distributors and other direct chicken purchasers, as well as related litigation from shareholders.Some of the allegations centre around producers’ use of the Georgia Dock, a widely used price index for wholesale chickens, which some people bringing the lawsuits claim was manipulated and artificially inflated by producers, a claim the companies have also denied. The Georgia Department of Agriculture, which oversees the benchmark index, said in December that it was suspending the weekly benchmark while it formulates a new price index.The legal scrutiny has cast a cloud over what was an otherwise upbeat set of quarterly earnings from Tyson earlier on Monday, which showed a 38 per cent year-on-year increase in earnings per share, to $1.59, while sales remained relatively flat at $9.18bn, compared to $9.15bn from the same quarter a year earlier. It also raised guidance for the upcoming year, predicting a 12 per cent increase in adjusted earnings per share from 2016, to come in at $4.90-$5.05, up from its previous forecast of $4.70-$4.85.

Titular: Brenda Barnes, consumer products executive, 1953-2017
Subtitular: Leader who found an equilibrium between boardroom and children
Texto: When Brenda Barnes resigned in 1997 as head of Pepsi-Cola for North America, little did she know it would reignite a fierce debate around work-life balance.Having shattered the glass ceiling to become one of the world’s most powerful businesswomen, by opting to focus on her three children she seemed to puncture something else instead — the idea that women could “have it all”.For Barnes, who has died aged 63, the decision had been purely personal. Nor were her following seven years restricted to the kitchen and the touchline of a school soccer pitch. She sat on boards including those of The New York Times and Sears, taught at Northwestern University and served as interim president of Starwood Hotels.Yet her resignation lingered. “My moment of fame in life was quitting my job . . . It’s not exactly what I aspired to,” she quipped at a speaking engagement at Stanford University in 2009.Then, in 2004, Barnes hit the financial and feminist headlines again — by snagging a top post at Sara Lee, where she was soon elevated to chief executive.Her return to the highest echelons of corporate America, once her offspring were older, suggested that perhaps women could indeed have it all — just not all at once. Reflecting on her experience, she established “returnships” for women at the company.Brenda Jo Czajka was born on November 11 1953 in Chicago, the third of seven daughters of a pipe fitter, who along with her mother shaped her strong work ethic. Her first job was sorting mail on the night shift at a post office — grunt work that she credited with giving her pointers in bringing dignity and an “element of fun” to a role.Graduating with a degree in economics from Illinois’ Augustana College, whose board she later chaired, Barnes joined Wilson Sporting Goods in 1976, then part of PepsiCo’s empire, while earning an MBA from Loyola University Chicago.In 1980 she moved to the parent soft drinks company and began to climb the ranks. In the same year she married colleague Randy Barnes, divorcing amicably after 26 years.At Sara Lee, Barnes set about selling off 40 per cent of the bakery-to-bras consumer group and battled to meet a self-imposed target of raising profit margins to 12 per cent from 8 per cent. Jon Harris, a friend who worked for her both there and at PepsiCo before joining ConAgra, says she advised him it was good “to be tough, as you owe it to shareholders, but it’s never an excuse to be mean. That was Brenda to a T.”Shedding many international and other operations enabled the company, renamed Hillshire Brands, to be acquired in the end by Tyson Foods.All the while, she was unafraid to let loose. In his eulogy for Barnes, Jim Nolan, another PepsiCo colleague who is now at Bimbo Bakeries USA, describes a work celebration with spouses. Leading the conga dance, “Brenda made a sharp turn and all of us in our cocktail attire, just like lemmings . . . followed her right into the pool . . . and then right out the other side.” He adds: “I lost a watch that night. But it didn’t matter — we would have followed her anywhere.”While her colleagues held her in high regard, she found tough love among some analysts — one of whom questioned her ability to lead a multinational after being a mum for several years. “I stayed calm didn’t throw anything at him, though I felt like it,” she told Stanford students, adding that mothers run much of society, from which they draw crucial experience. “I learnt I have to have a thick skin [or] else it gets in the way, and there’s too much to get done.”In 2010 she suffered a stroke, forcing her to step down from Sara Lee. Barnes, who succumbed last month to another stroke, is survived by her children and Sal Barrutia, her partner of eight years.During her career, the advance of technology came to offer women a wider range of ways to combine work and family. Bigger numbers of male executives are also seeking a form of work-life balance that suits them.Still, “if anything, the Brenda Barnes story speaks to how few role models we have”, says Samantha Ettus, an author and speaker on women and the workplace. “If there were thousands of Fortune 1,000 current and former female CEOs, then one woman’s story wouldn’t be used as an example for an entire gender. Because we have ridiculously few women CEOs, each woman’s story takes on too much weight.”Barnes herself never sought to be a role model. It was all about being good at her job, trying to make a success of parenthood too, and juggling those priorities accordingly — whether hour by hour or year by year.Lindsay Whipp

Titular: Tyson shares plunge on profit guidance and chief’s departure
Subtitular: Meat producer’s sales fall 13% amid decline in demand
Texto: Shares in Tyson Foods, one of the world’s largest meat producers, on Monday suffered their worst fall in eight years after the company said profits for next year would come in below analyst forecasts and it announced the departure of its chief executive.The stock, which had been up more than 26 per cent for the year in the run-up to the fourth-quarter earnings report, plunged 17.3 per cent to a nine-and-a-half-month low of $55.72, slicing nearly $3.5bn off Tyson’s market value.Tyson said Donnie Smith would be stepping down at the end of the year as chief executive, a role he has held since 2009. He will be replaced by president Tom Hayes, who oversaw supply chains at Hillshire Brands, the maker of lunch meats and Ball Park hot dogs that was acquired by Tyson in 2014.The news came as Tyson unveiled a disappointing end to what had been an outstanding fiscal year.For the three months to October 1, sales fell 13 per cent from the same period the year before to $9.15bn — against $9.4bn expected by analysts — amid declining demand for chicken, beef and pork. In the company’s all-important beef division the weaker trend was compounded by a near 15 per cent fall in average prices during the quarter.However, profits jumped more than 51 per cent to $391m, as lower feed prices and lower interest and tax expenses helped pad the bottom line. Earnings per diluted share came in at $1.03, short of the $1.16 the market had forecast, despite $600m in share buybacks during the period.Mr Smith acknowledged in a conference call that the results were “slightly below our internal expectations”, but were poised to rebound in 2017 as chicken and pork demand improves and livestock costs fall faster than retail prices.“We’re growing where we want to grow by selling more branded, higher-margin products,” Mr Smith said.Nonetheless, investors appeared rattled by Tyson’s earnings guidance for next year. After several quarters of heady growth, sending shares to a record high of $77.05 in September, the company said it expects earnings per share for fiscal 2017 to come in between $4.70 and $4.85, a 4 to 7 per cent increase from 2016 but below the $4.98 the market was projecting.

Titular: Tyson shares crater after CEO exits, outlook disappoints
Texto: Tyson Food shares are having their worst day in over eight years on Monday as investors brace for a period of slower growth after the meat processor issued a stinging profit outlook for next year and announced the surprise departure of its chief executive.The stock, which had been up more than 26 per cent for the year ahead of today’s earnings, plunged by as much as 17.3 per cent to a nine-and-half month low of $55.72 on the news.The decline marks the shares’ biggest one day drop since November 2008 and sliced nearly $3.5bn off the company’s market value.Tyson said in a statement that Donnie Smith will be stepping down as chief executive at the end of the year following seven years on the job. He will be replaced by president Tom Hayes, who oversaw supply chains at Hillshire Brands, the maker of lunch meats and Ball Park hot dogs maker that was acquired by Tyson in 2014.News of the transition comes as Tyson, one of the world’s largest meat producers, unveiled a disappointing end to what had been an outstanding fiscal 2016 year.For the three months to October 1, sales fell 13 per cent to $9.15bn compared to the prior year period amid a sharp drop off in demand for chicken, beef and pork. The decline was far steeper than the drop to $9.4bn analysts were expecting and was led by the company’s all important beef division where the the weaker volume trend was compounded by a near 15 per cent drop in average prices during the period.Fiscal fourth quarter profits jumped more than 51 per cent to $391m however, as lower feed prices and lower interest and tax expenses helped pad the bottom line. Earnings per share, came in at $1.03 per diluted share. While the figure was flattered by the $600m in share buybacks the company enacted during the quarter, it still came in short of the $1.16 a share the market had forecast.Mr Smith acknowledged in a conference call with investors that the results were “slightly below our internal expectations,” but said it expects things to pick up in 2017 as chicken and pork demand improve and livestock costs fall faster than retail prices.“We’re growing where we want to grow by selling more branded, higher margin products,” Mr Smith said.Nonetheless, investors appeared spooked by Tyson’s earnings guidance for next year. After several quarters of heady growth, which helped send shares to a record high of $77.05 earlier in September, the company said it expects earnings per share for the fiscal 2017 year to come in at between $4.70-$4.85, a 4-7 per cent increase from 2016 but below the $4.98 the market was projecting.

Titular: Wall St struggles to add to record run
Texto: Wall Street struggled to add to its record run on Monday as investors took a breather after pushing two of the three main benchmark indices to fresh highs last Friday.The S&P 500 hit a new all time high of 2,182.87 and the Nasdaq Composite struck a new closing high on Friday after non-farm payrolls data showed the US economy added a better-than-expected 255,000 jobs in July.The gains, which represented the second straight month of strong jobs growth, were the latest evidence that the US economy is enjoying a “Goldilocks” moment right now – that is, growth is humming along, but not fast enough for the central bank to rush to raise interest rates.But confidence over the health of the world’s most important economy was not enough to help US stocks extend their rally on Monday.The main indices all struggled for direction and were fluctuating between minor gains and minor losses in early morning trading.At pixel time, both the S&P 500 and the Dow were down 0.1 per cent, while the Nasdaq fell 0.3 per cent.With the earnings season more than three-quarters of the way through, investors also appeared to be cheered by the better than expected results so far. About 78 per cent of firms that have reported have beaten profit predictions and 56 per cent have topped sales projections, according to Bloomberg data.Tyson Foods was the latest to beat analysts estimates and raised full year expectations on Monday. Other companies due to report this week include News Corp., Walt Disney and Macy’s.Yields on the 10 year Treasury bond edged 0.2 basis points lower to 1.58 per cent. The dollar extended its gains from last week, with the DXY index rising 0.2 per cent to 96.38.

Titular: Tyson beefs up forecast, shares jump
Texto: Tyson Foods is beefing up its earnings outlook once again.The US’s biggest meat processor saw its shares jump more than 3 per cent in pre-market trading on Monday after it raised its earnings forecast for the year and delivered a bumper set of third quarter results.Sales for the three months to July 2 were down 4.1 per cent at $9.4bn amid lower beef prices and weaker chicken and pork consumption. However, this was more than offset by lower feed and livestock costs, which helped boost profit margins and drove net income at the company up 41 per cent to $484m for the period.The market had forecast sales of $9.33bn. Operating profit margins rose to 8.2 per cent for the quarter, compared to 5.6 per cent during the prior year period.Expectations that input costs will remain depressed prompted the Arkansas-based group to raise its earnings guidance for the third time this year.It now expects adjusted earnings per share for the fiscal 2016 year to come in $4.47-$4.57 , compared to its previous estimate of $4.20-$4.30.Tyson shares, up 76 per cent over the past 12 months, hit a fresh intraday record high of $74.85 last week. The stock is expected surpass that level when the market opens on Monday.

Titular: Freeport-McMoRan declines after mine stake deal
Subtitular: S&P 500 healthcare sector posts biggest gain among US stocks
Texto: Copper miner Freeport-McMoRan was the biggest decliner on the S&P 500 after the company said it was selling its stake in a vast Congo copper mine to China Molybdenum as it steps up efforts to reduce a debt burden.Under the terms of the $2.65bn cash deal announced on Monday, Freeport will sell its 70 per cent stake in Bermuda Holdings company TF Holdings, which indirectly owns an 80 per cent interest in Tenke Fungurume Mining — a copper mining project in the Katanga province of the Democratic Republic of Congo.Freeport could receive an additional $120m if prices for copper and cobalt reach a certain level between 2018 and 2019.But investors reacted negatively and sent Freeport shares 10.9 per cent lower to $10.51. Analysts at Jefferies said this was an “excellent deal” for Freeport, however.A fall in oil and copper prices has affected Freeport’s ability to pay down its debt burden. Net debt stood at more than $20bn at the end of March, compared with the company’s market capitalisation of $15.4bn.Freeport shares have advanced more than 55 per cent so far this year following a 71 per cent drop in 2015.The drop in Freeport came on day when US stocks fluctuated between gains and losses. At the close, the S&P 500 was little changed at 2,058.7, the Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped 0.2 per cent to 17,705.9 and the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.3 per cent to 4,750.2.The S&P 500 healthcare sector posted the biggest gain on the benchmark index, rising 1.1 per cent. The rally was led by a 6 per cent advance in Allergan shares to $213.71.Sotheby’s shares fell by as much as 8.5 per cent in early trade after the New York auction house swung to a loss in the first three months of the year. However, news that an outside investor was considering building up a 10 per cent stake in the group gave its shares a boost, as they closed the day 6 per cent higher at $28.91.The company slid to a loss of $25.9m, or 41 cents a share, in the first quarter, compared with a profit of $5.2m, or 7 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales fell 32 per cent to $106.5m. Analysts on Wall Street were looking for a loss of 27 cents a share on sales of $120m.Sotheby’s noted the global art market has two selling seasons, which occur in the second and fourth quarter of the year and that the company typically reports lower sales and net losses in the first and third quarter.After posting a 35 per cent drop in net auction sales in the first quarter, Thomas Smith, chief executive, also noted that “this week’s sale of impressionist, modern and contemporary art are smaller than a year ago, down 38 per cent at the midpoint of our expected ranges”.Shares in Tyson Foods climbed 1.5 per cent to $68.24 after the meat producer reported stronger-than-expected profits and lifted its earnings outlook for the year.The Arkansas-based company reported fiscal second-quarter profits of $432m, or $1.10 a share, on sales of $9.2bn, topping analysts’ estimates.The group also lifted its full-year earnings outlook to a range of $4.20 to $4.30 a share, up from $3.85 to $3.95 a share, ahead of forecasts.Krispy Kreme shares jumped 24.3 per cent to $20.96 after JAB Beech said it would acquire the US doughnut chain for $21 a share in cash, in a deal with an equity value of about $1.35bn.

Titular: Tyson shares hit new high after profit guidance boost
Texto: Tyson Foods is flying high.Shares in the US meat processor climbed to a new record high on Monday after the company raised its full year earnings guidance and delivered better than expected fiscal second quarter results.Sales for the March quarter were down 8.1 per cent at $9.17bn amid lower beef, chicken and pork prices. However, this was more than offset by falling corn and soybean meal feed costs, which helped boost profit margins and drove net income at the company up 39 per cent to $432m for the period.Tyson said it reaped the benefit of $95m in lower input cost during the quarter while gross profit margins rose to 12.9 per cent from 9.9 per cent the prior year period.Expectations that grain costs will remain depressed has prompted the Arkansas-based group to raise its earnings guidance for the year.It now sees adjusted earnings for fiscal 2016 at $4.20-4.30 per share, compared to its previous forecast of $3.85 to $3.95 a share.The stock gained by as much as 4.7 per cent in response, taking its year to date gains to more than 28 per cent.

Titular: Healthy bars and nibbles reshape US snacks market
Subtitular: Busier lifestyles and demographic shifts help change consumer tastes
Texto: Daniel Lubetzky became tired of waiting for a company to produce the sort of healthy snacks he craved. So he started making his own.“In the early 2000s, I was travelling a lot and kept finding that there weren’t healthy snacks available that tasted good and satisfied my hunger,” social entrepreneur Mr Lubetzky says. “These frustrations with my own snacking options sparked the idea for Kind.”He was not the only one with cravings for healthy snacks. Kind Snacks, which makes nut and fruit bars, sells its products in 150,000 stores, with sales rising 36 per cent last year. It is one of many start-ups either taking on America’s food giants in the growing healthier snack sector — or being bought by them.Sales of snacks — including bakery snacks, biscuits, confectionery, ice cream, snack bars, yoghurt and savoury snacks — jumped 17.4 per cent to $145bn in the five years to 2015, according to Euromonitor. This growth is being driven by products which are perceived as more healthy, analysts and executives say. And they are confident that trend will continue.“It’s certainly going to continue to be one of our growth platforms,” says James Snee, chief operating officer at Hormel Foods in a recent interview. “At our core we’re protein based so the idea of being able to . . . take from traditional formats [and transform] into snacking formats serves us well.”US sales of energy and nutrition bars have surged 87.5 per cent to $2.48bn in the five years to 2015, while nuts have increased 34.7 per cent to $4.55bn, fruit bars have risen 16.5 per cent to $1.17bn and yoghurt has risen 26.8 per cent to $8.38bn, according to Euromonitor.The shift towards foods perceived to be healthier is changing America’s food industry, and this is particularly the case in snacks. For a number of years, consumers have been more aware of the types of food they eat amid a nationwide obesity and diabetes type 2 crisis.Busier lifestyles and a more diverse population is also driving the rise in snacking, highlighting the growing importance of convenience. Driven by millennials, consumers are eating on the go more often than in the past, sometimes using snacks to replace meals, executives say. The average consumer eats five times a day, Tyson Foods points out. A shift to city dwelling means smaller kitchens for some and less cooking.Everyone is trying to get a piece of the snacking market. It’s bringing in a lot of companies“The traditional image of mom and dad sitting down for dinner at 6pm with two children . . . is as outdated as the typewriter,” Denise Morrison, chief executive of Campbell Soup, recently told investors. “We live in a polycultural society with diverse tastes and norms. The one size fits all approach is long gone.”But what exactly is a healthier snack? There is no single definition and what consumers find important health wise can change over time and between generations. For some, the focus on weight loss or low carbohydrates has shifted to eating less processed fare even if it is not so low in fat.Protein has become a focus, leading to a renaissance in high-end jerky sales, but the product still contains relatively high salt levels. And some nutrition bars may contain largely unprocessed ingredients but still have sugar levels comparable to candy bars.A key trend at the moment is having only simple and recognisable ingredients in food — known as clean labelling. This means free from artificial colours, preservatives and additives. Organic continues to grow in popularity as does GMO-free food.“The things that people are most worried about vary,” says Alexia Howard, an analyst at Bernstein. “Over the past two or three years, there has been a massive conversation online about fillers and preservatives. There’s definitely been opting for ‘I don’t want artificial’.”Leaders in the snacks market, such as PepsiCo’s Frito-Lay and Mondelez, have for some time been introducing products and technology aimed at removing the guilt from indulging. Pepsi in December introduced a smart vending machine selling its “better for you” snacks with a digital function that gives nutritional information. Meanwhile, Mondelez is targeting half of its sales to come from its “wellbeing” snacks, up from a third now.Demand for healthier snacks has lured companies who previously had little or no exposure to the category as well as newer companies such as Kind and Graze of the UK, which sells trays of nuts and dried fruit via online subscription.Abbott Laboratories — a nutrition and medical devices company — this month introduced its first new range of snack bars in more than a decade.Tyson, a relative newcomer to snacks via its Hillshire brands acquisition, is capitalising on “gourmet” jerky sales, as is chocolate maker Hershey, which has bought jerky brand Krave.“Everyone is trying to get a piece of the snacking market,” says Jared Koerton, a senior food analyst at Euromonitor. “It’s bringing in a lot of companies into a new market [for them], or ones trying to expand into new product areas.”

Titular: LinkedIn slides amid glum forecasts
Subtitular: Consumer and technology stocks weigh heavily on the S&P 500
Texto: LinkedIn shares were hit by heavy losses on Friday after the professional networking site revealed a glum outlook for 2016.The California-based company said it expects sales this year of $3.6bn to $3.65bn, shy of Wall Street forecasts of $3.71bn.Its estimate of adjusted profits of $3.05 to $3.20 a share also trailed expectations of $3.71 a share.The shares closed down 43.63 per cent to $108.38 in what was by far the worst day since LinkedIn made its public market debut in 2011. It also yanked about $10bn from its market value.LinkedIn generates the bulk of its sales through services that utilise its userbase to provide products that help companies find job candidates and generate business-to-business sales.That is one reason why analysts homed in on LinkedIn’s announcement that it will close its Lead Accelerator business, which it launched only last year.LinkedIn said demand for the product that lets companies target ads to specific audiences was “solid,” but it “required more resources than anticipated to scale”.LinkedIn plans to incorporate the technology into its Sponsored Content unit but may take a $50m hit to revenue this year as part of the plan, it said.Analysts said the move represented a gamble that could pay off by helping LinkedIn focus more closely on businesses that it can grow, but some wondered if LinkedIn was too quick to dismiss a group with substantial potential.“We think it is making a gigantic mistake stepping back on investment in its ad network,” said Evan Wilson, an analyst at Pacific Crest, in a note to clients.Three Wall Street banks downgraded the stock to hold on Friday.Shares in US oil company Hess fell 12.54 per cent to $38.02 after it priced a stock sale to strengthen its balance sheet amid a slump in crude prices that began nearly 20 months ago.The sale is made up of 25m shares at $39 a piece and 10m depository shares at $50 a share, which could see the company raise about $1.4bn after deducting certain fees.Hess, which last week reported its first annual loss in 13 years, said it will also use the money for its “longer term capital needs”.Hanesbrands was the biggest decliner on the S&P 500, falling more than 15 per cent to $24.96, after the retailer issued a 2016 sales outlook that missed analysts’ expectations.The North Carolina-based company said it expects sales of $5.8bn to $5.9bn in fiscal 2016, below analysts’ forecasts for $6.3bn.That came alongside fourth-quarter profits of $119.2m or 30 cents a share, and sales that declined 7.4 per cent to $1.4bn, also shy of estimates.Shares in Tyson Foods jumped as much as 13.5 per cent to a record high of $58.95 after the US meat processor raised its full-year profit forecast as feed costs declined. They closed 9.9 per cent up.The Arkansas-based company now expects fiscal 2016 earnings in the range of $3.85 to $3.95 a share, up from $3.50 to $3.65 a share. That topped analysts’ expectations for $3.63 a share.Consumer and technology stocks weighed heavily on the S&P 500. By the close, the S&P 500 was down 1.85 per cent to 1,879.91, the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 1.29 per cent to 16,203.49 and the Nasdaq Composite fell 3.25 per cent to 4,363.43.

Titular: Digital downloads weigh on GameStop
Subtitular: US stocks receive early boost from energy and material sectors
Texto: GameStop was the biggest decliner on the S&P 500 at one stage on Monday after the US video game retailer reported weaker than expected third-quarter results, citing disappointing gaming software and hardware sales.The Texas-based company said adjusted profits fell 11 per cent to $57m or 54 cents a share in the three months ended in October, shy of analysts’ estimates for 59 cents a share. Revenues fell 3.6 per cent to $2bn, shy of forecasts.New video game software sales, which accounted for almost a third of its revenue last year, fell 20.4 per cent.Meanwhile, new hardware, which accounted for almost 22 per cent of its 2014 revenue, fell 9.3 per cent.Retailers such as GameStop have been under pressure as consumers download games digitally at an increasing rate instead of buying physical versions.This weighs on the retailer in two key ways, said Anthony Chukumba, an analyst at BB&T Capital Markets.“GameStop does not have nearly as high market share in digital games than physical ones,” he said. “This results in fewer trade-ins of used games, which generate much higher profit margins for GameStop than new ones.”For the current quarter, the company expects comparable sales in the range of -1 per cent to 6 per cent growth, compared with analysts’ estimates for 4.3 per cent growth.GameStop expects adjusted earnings in the range of $2.12 to $2.32 a share, below expectations.Shares in GameStop fell 15 per cent to $33.53 in early trading, taking the stock’s year-to-date decline to 0.2 per cent. They later rallied to end down 4.2 per cent at $37.6.Tyson Foods shares advanced 10.17 per cent to $48.09 after the US meat processor reported better than expected full-year earnings outlook and fourth quarter sales, driven by demand for its chicken and prepared foods products.The Arkansas-based company said sales increased 4 per cent to $10.5bn in the fiscal fourth quarter, ahead of estimates.Sales in chicken, Tyson’s second-biggest division, climbed 8 per cent to $3bn, and in its prepared foods products to $2bn in the fourth quarter, buoyed by its acquisition of Hillshire Brands last year.Operating profits climbed to $150m from a loss of $47m in the year ago period.However, beef, Tyson’s largest division, swung to an operating loss of $33m while sales slid modestly to $4.4bn.Profits rose to $258m or 63 cents a share from $137m or 35 cents a share in the year-ago period but were below forecasts for earnings of 86 cents a share.For fiscal 2016, the company forecast adjusted earnings in the range of $3.50 to $3.65 a share, ahead of expectations for $3.52.Pfizer and Allergan shares were under pressure after they agreed to a $160bn tie-up, the largest merger in the pharmaceuticals industry.Pfizer shares fell 2.7 per cent to $31.33 while shares in Allergan fell 3.6 per cent to $301.70.Alcoa shares advanced 4.37 per cent to $9.07 after Elliott Management, the activist investor, revealed it had taken a stake in the aluminium producer.The S&P 500 advanced early on Monday led by gains in the energy and material sectors, but ended down 0.12 per cent at 2,086.59. The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.17 per cent to 17,792.68, and the Nasdaq Composite was almost flat at 5,102.48.mamta.badkar@ft.comTwitter: @mamtabadkar

Titular: China: never mind the bullocks
Subtitular: Trend towards higher meat consumption globally is clear. As societies get richer, diets add protein
Texto: Have a yen to own a cow? Can do, through “My Cow,” creation of a privately owned Australian company. Targeting the Chinese market, customers can buy a whole cow — available to visit, but ultimately for delivery in parts.In the past year, more ambitious buyers have bought cattle ranches, too. Chinese bidders are reportedly interested in purchasing Australia’s biggest private landholding, which is on the block.The trend towards higher meat consumption worldwide is clear. As societies get richer, diets add protein.In China, since 2003, meat eaten per capita has risen by a quarter, to 57kg, according a report from consultants PwC. It would have to grow another 30 per cent to catch up with Taiwan.With livestock requiring more resources per calorie than other foods, demand for grains and feedstocks is also likely to rise.China’s quest for food has already resulted in many mergers and acquisitions — nearly $20bn of cross-border deals in the past five years alone, according to Dealogic.Targets have ranged from grain trader Noble Agri, in which Chinese entities bought a majority stake last year, to US based pork rearing and processing company Smithfield.Gaining exposure to this growth story is not straightforward. Despite the generally, um, bullish backdrop, recent pronouncements from US listed meat companies have been downbeat.Beef producer Tyson Foods’ latest quarterly results missed forecasts due in part to an oversupply of beef, weak Chinese demand and the strong dollar. Poor export performance was a drag at chicken producer Pilgrim’s Pride, too.Shares in US meat producers are at least cheap, at mid-teens multiples of 2016 earnings. And the Chinese demand boost will last longer than the current supply cycle and perhaps even the strong dollar.In the meantime JBS, Brazil-listed meat producer and parent of Pilgrim’s Pride, reports in reals, and 90 per cent of output is exported. Next: My Cow in Brazil.This note has been amended to reflect that Chinese entities bought a majority stake in Noble Agri, not Singapore-listed Noble Group as first stated.Email the Lex team at lex@ft.com

Titular: Tyson Foods slides on earnings miss
Subtitular: US equities start new month on the defensive as energy sector slides
Texto: US meat processor Tyson Foods was one of the worst performing stocks on the benchmark S&P 500 after the company cut its full-year earnings forecast, reflecting higher cattle prices’ eroding margins on its beef unit.The Arkansas-based company now expects full-year adjusted earnings in the range of $3.10 to $3.20 a share, below its previous forecast for earnings of $3.30 to $3.40. That was shy of Wall Street forecasts for earnings of $3.44 a share.Beef, Tyson’s biggest division, which accounted for 42 per cent of group sales last year, fell into an operating loss of $7m for the quarter, compared with an operating profit of $101m last year, due to higher cattle costs.The company said it sold beef at lower values in other markets rather than build up inventory because of the West Coast port strikes. Tyson said its beef business was also impacted after feedlots fell behind on their marketing schedules, leaving the company with a low supply.Tyson warned that the unit should be “near break-even for fiscal 2015 and profitable, but below its normalised range” of 2.5 to 4.5 per cent for fiscal 2016, as a result of the “imbalance of fed cattle supply and demand”.The news came alongside disappointing third-quarter results. Tyson said weaker export prospects as a result of the stronger dollar shaved $84m off its third-quarter results.The company reported profits of $343m, or 83 cents a share, compared with $260m, or 73 cents a share. Sales rose 4 per cent to $10.1bn.Analysts had forecast earnings of 93 cents a share, on sales of $10.3bn.Shares in Tyson Foods, which are up 8 per cent over the past year, fell 9.9 per cent to $39.96.Michael Kors shares fell 7.9 per cent to $38.66 as analysts at Piper Jaffray lowered their price target from $44 to $38.“Our checks suggest inventory for Michael Kors is building at retailers like Macy’s & Dillard’s,” Erinn Murphy, an analyst at Piper Jaffray said. “Watches remain under pressure in the US and are starting to slow in Europe.”Shares of Loews, a provider of commercial property insurance and a hotels and energy conglomerate, fell 2.8 per cent to $37.03 after the company reported second-quarter profits that were shy of analysts forecasts.The New York-based company reported profits of $170m, or 46 cents a share, compared with $116m, or 30 cents a share, in the period a year prior. This missed analysts estimates for earnings of 66 cents a share. Sales fell more than 4 per cent to $3.4bn.Loews said its operating profits for the quarter fell after the drop in crude prices weighed on Diamond Offshore, the company’s second largest subsidiary, accounting for 20 per cent of overall revenue in 2014.US stocks began the week on the back foot after a 5 per cent drop in the price of Brent crude pushed the S&P 500 energy index 2 per cent lower.The S&P 500 slipped 0.3 per cent to 2,098.04, the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.5 per cent to 17,598.20. The Nasdaq Composite fell 0.3 per cent to 5,115.38.mamta.badkar@ft.comTwitter: @mamtabadkar

Titular: Review: Myths and Mortals by Andrew Keyt
Subtitular: Advice on how to keep businesses within the family and pitfalls to avoid
Texto: There are many pitfalls in family businesses: nepotism, feuds between relatives, as well as the mythologies that swirl around the leaders. Take, for example, Rupert Murdoch, a towering figure in charge of a vast media empire whose children, standing in the shadows, are often portrayed as pale substitutes.The author describes how such myths can be damaging. Larger than life, the leaders of a family business bring with them stories of heroism and history. Their successes seem impossible to replicate.There is good reason for wanting such companies to do well. Family businesses are important to the economy. According to the not-for-profit Institute for Family Business, two-thirds of UK businesses are family-owned; they generate more than a quarter of UK gross domestic product and employ about 9.9m people.Yet they are often characterised as old-fashioned and constrained by the ties that bind a family. The belief is that family-owned companies can only do well if they behave like public companies, says the author. However, he insists that the opposite is true.Such businesses have a myriad of areas where they outperform public companies, particularly when it comes to survival rates. This is because, the author asserts, “families who work together toward a legacy tend to stay together — and their businesses thrive”. However, he fails to untangle the dynamics of a publicly listed company dominated by a family.The author has talked to successors of family business legends, including Christie Hefner, former chief executive of Playboy Enterprises, and John Tyson, chairman of Tyson Foods, as well as drawing on his own experiences having served as manager in two family-owned companies and running the Loyola University Chicago Next Generation Leadership Institute.There are some mistakes, Keyt notes, that can keep a successor in the shadows — idealisation of the leader as well as infantilisation of the family member who will succeed. Idealisation can lead to parent-pleasing and the older one gets, according to Keyt, the harder it becomes to step out of their shadow.“The patterns become so ingrained, the belief systems hardened,” he writes. “If a parent is building an empire, a child reasons, the stories explain their parent’s absence and why they always felt like a runner-up in the pick of priorities.”Whereas infantilisation keeps children immature, cosseted from harsh realities and put in a position they are not up to. It means the parent will swoop back in to save the day, reinforcing their dependency. Keyt advises parents and children that separation and defining one’s own success is vital.The most common of the parents’ fears, the author says, is that the children will feel entitled and squander the family fortune. There is plenty of advice for successors and leaders as well as exercises to discover whether you are ready to hand over or take over.After all, the consequences are not just professional, they are also personal. Bella Hoare of C Hoare & Co, is quoted giving this advice: “Don’t join until you’re damn sure you want to stay there . . . leaving your family business makes you almost unemployable.”The reviewer is a writer for Business Life

Titular: Bumper harvest boosts Cargill profits
Subtitular: World’s largest agricultural trader reaps benefit of record US corn and soyabeans crops
Texto: Cargill, the food commodities trader, raked in bumper profits during a quarter in which farmers across North America harvested huge crops.The $784m in net profit reported for the fiscal second quarter to November 30, up 41 per cent from $556m a year before, ranked as the company’s best result in four years.As the world’s largest agricultural processor and trader, Cargill’s earnings are watched as a harbinger for listed competitors such as Archer Daniels Midland and Bunge, as well as meat companies such as Tyson Foods.Cargill’s performance has been uneven in recent years, due in part to crop shortfalls and trading losses. In its latest quarter, the company said it ably handled the record US harvest of corn and soyabeans and large volumes of grain sales from Canada.David MacLennan, Cargill chief executive, said: “Just as last quarter’s focus was on getting ready for North America’s big harvest, the current quarter was all about execution. Our team did an excellent job serving farmer customers and fully utilising our supply chains to meet domestic and export demand.”At the same time, Cargill’s results were somewhat offset by the effects of South American farmers who are hoarding grain and delaying sales as a hedge against inflation.With operations spanning dozens of countries, Cargill is an important middleman between surplus producers and importers. It is also one of the largest privately owned companies in the world, with revenue of $135bn in its latest full fiscal year.Our team did an excellent job serving farmer customers and fully utilising our supply chains to meet domestic and export demandAgricultural trading houses tend to have better returns when they are running assets such as silos and processing plants at high rates of capacity, which has been a challenge after the weather-related supply disruptions of the past few years.That has begun to change as bumper crops across the northern hemisphere allow stocks to build. Cargill’s origination and processing division was the biggest contributor to quarterly results, the company said. BMO Capital Markets said its earnings rose 50 per cent year on year. Cargill did not provide specific data on segment performance.Cargill is also a large meat supplier, processing poultry, pork and beef. Strong sales of turkeys over the US Thanksgiving holiday were among the factors that helped to boost its animal nutrition and protein division, which BMO said enjoyed a 48 per cent rise in quarterly earnings.In November, Cargill said its branding of birds raised without growth-promoting antibiotics in the US helped aid demand.In an interview with the Financial Times last year, Mr MacLennan said Cargill’s performance was not meeting his expectations after several years of disappointing results. About 100 descendants of company founder William Wallace Cargill own about 90 per cent of its common stock.

Titular: Continental Grain warns on margins in US chicken business
Subtitular: Chairman says group is considering a float as the commodities cycle might be about to turn
Texto: Plump profit margins in the US chicken business may be about to fly the coop, a top food and agriculture investor warned as he hinted at listing shares in a poultry producer he controls.Chicken farmers have dined out on fat profits in the past year thanks to abundant global feed grain supplies and strong demand for poultry as a cheaper alternative to beef.But Paul Fribourg, chairman and chief executive of Continental Grain company, told a New York forum on Wednesday that the commodities cycle might be about to turn.Privately held Continental, a well-known name in global commodities that was founded 201 years ago, owns Wayne Farms, the sixth-largest poultry producer in the US with more than $1.9bn in annual sales, according to its website.Mr Fribourg said the chicken industry reached its nadir several years ago, when US chicken producer Pilgrim’s Pride and others filed for bankruptcy.“We were at the low of the commodities cycle in chicken, because grain prices were very high and chicken prices were low. So there was an opportunity to go out and buy very cheap chicken companies,” Mr Fribourg said.“Today the cycle has gone to the other extreme, where you have incredibly high chicken prices and very low grain prices,” he added. “It’s not going to last. So at the top of the cycle we’re now looking at ways to lock in either long-term margins, or possibly, for example, take our chicken company public.”Continental is a leading investor in food and commodities, having taken stakes in companies including Burger King and Smithfield Foods, the pork producer bought last year by China’s Shuanghui International, now called WH Group.Mr Fribourg is the sixth generation descendant of Simon Fribourg, who founded the family business in Belgium in 1813. He rarely discusses business in public.The US poultry business has bounced back spectacularly from lean years. Shares of listed US poultry producer Sanderson Farms have risen 86 per cent in the past two years, while Tyson Foods – the largest chicken company and also a beef and pork supplier – has seen its share price double.Profit margins in the chicken business are “pretty sensational,” said Bill Lapp of Advanced Economic Solutions, a food and agriculture consultant. “It’s an industry that’s doing well and could remain in good shape into early 2015.”However, Mr Lapp said the fragmented poultry industry had historically seen farmers expand flocks too fast, sabotaging their own success. “Their mantra tends to be ‘No profit shall go unpunished’,” he said.

Titular: Tyson Foods: there’s the beef
Subtitular: Low commodity prices boosted quarterly forecasts, but also add to risk
Texto: Beef is judged by its cut. But a steak is judged by how it is cooked. Shares in US meat producer Tyson Foods dropped in July when it agreed to spend $8.6bn on rival Hillshire Brands. The deal seemed too expensive. But Tyson has pushed on regardless, and its operations look strong. This week it reported record quarterly results, beating forecasts thanks to low commodity prices. But that is where the risk lies too.Shares in all large meat producers have jumped over the past two years. Tyson is up 70 per cent; Sanderson Farms is up nearly 80 per cent; and Pilgrim’s Pride is up threefold. That is because cereal stocks – used for chicken, cattle and hog feed – have been steadily rising due to bumper crops in Europe and China. The bigger the stocks, the cheaper the feed. The price of wheat middlings, a common ingredient in cattle feed, is a third lower than it was a year ago, for example. That goes through to the bottom line. Profits at Sanderson Farms doubled in the first nine months of this year due to lower costs.Is this sustainable? According to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the UN, feed stocks will rise to 25 per cent of annual consumption next year, the highest level in more than a decade. But prices can still vary. Soyabean meal prices have been rallying since the start of October, when they hit a 33-month low. Scarcity is not the problem. Lack of rail cars in the Midwest is. Shale oil and gas is crowding out grain trains, among other issues.Tight supplies of beef, which this year enabled Tyson to push its prices up 22 per cent, are set to stay. This is good for the entire industry. Demand is expected to rise as the US economy improves and consumers appetite for red meat swells.Tyson is undervalued compared with peers – the Hillshire deal still weighs on the price. But on 11 times earnings versus 18 for Sanderson, it offers some juicy cuts for investors seeking proteins.Email the Lex team at lex@ft.com

Titular: Tyson jumps after record sales
Subtitular: US stocks slip after four straight weeks of gains
Texto: US meat producer Tyson Foods was one of the best-performing stocks on the S&P 500 after beating adjusted fourth-quarter earnings forecasts.The company reported net income of $137m or 35 cents a share in the three months ended in September compared with $261m or 71 cents a share in the year-ago period.Sales gained nearly 14 per cent to a record $10.1bn, driven by higher beef prices.Wall Street analysts were looking for earnings of 73 cents a share on sales of $10.3bn. Adjusting for one-time items, earnings of 87 cents a share topped forecasts for 77 cents a share.The company expects more growth and increased profitability in the chicken and prepared foods segment.Donnie Smith, chief executive of Tyson Foods, said the company’s acquisition of prepared foods maker Hillshire Brands earlier this year will be seen as “a watershed event”.For fiscal 2015, the company projected earnings in the range of $3.30-3.40 a share.Wall Street analysts had forecast guidance of $3.33 a share. The company expects that elevated beef and pork prices will help boost chicken demand by 3 per cent over the next few years.Shares in Tyson Foods gained 6 per cent to $43.03 and are up 29 per cent so far this year.Apple climbed as much as 2.7 per cent before paring its gains in early morning trading on Monday, touching $117.28, or $820.96 when adjusting for the company’s June 7-for-1 share split.The gain puts it above a price target analysts across Wall Street had set in autumn 2012 as shares pushed past $700 in anticipation of the iPad Mini launch.On average, analysts had laid out a 12-month price target of $780 in September 2012, data from Bloomberg shows.Lacklustre results, however, and rising concern that competition would cut into its growth soured sentiment and sunk Apple shares over the following eight months.The company’s shares have since recovered, buoyed by aggressive share buybacks, strong sales of a new flagship smartphone and the release of Apple Pay.Allergan shares gained 5 per cent to $209.20 after the Botox maker agreed to a $66bn deal with Actavis.Actavis said it will pay $219 for each Allergan share, valuing the Botox maker at $66bn.On hearing the news, Canadian drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals, which has had its takeover offers rebuffed, said that it “cannot justify to its own shareholders paying a price of $219 or more per share for Allergan”.Actavis shares gained nearly 2 per cent to $247.94.Halliburton, the world’s second-largest oil services company, agreed to buy Baker Hughes for $38bn. Shares in Baker Hughes soared 9 per cent to $65.23. The deal does, however, face regulatory hurdles.US stocks were mixed after four straight weeks of advances after industrial production data missed expectations and the Japanese economy unexpectedly entered into a recession in the third quarter.The S&P 500 rose 0.1 per cent to 2,041.32, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.1 per cent at 17,647.75. The Nasdaq Composite slipped 0.4 per cent to 4,671.00.Email: mamta.badkar@ft.comTwitter: @mamtabadkar

Titular: RBC pushes aggressively into US dealmaking market
Subtitular: Canadian lender now earns more than half its investment banking revenue in US
Texto: When Tyson Foods launched its $8.5bn bid for Hillshire, the hot-dog maker, Royal Bank of Canada found itself facing a difficult decision.At the point Tyson entered the fray, the battle to control America’s processed food industry was sizzling. Hillshire, already the target of a bid from Pilgrim’s Pride, was itself pursuing the acquisition of pickle and frozen meals producer Pinnacle Foods.RBC, which had relationships with all four companies, had to choose who to team up with.It was not always so. In years past, the Toronto-headquartered bank was a peripheral operator in the US M&A market, outgunned by the traditional Wall Street institutions – and more aggressive foreign rivals – when competing for deal mandates.But the expansion of RBC’s investment banking operations in the US, fuelled by an aggressive hiring spree, has been pronounced during the past five years.So far this year, RBC has collected fees of $856.6m in the US, according to data from Thomson Reuters, more than triple the $262.4m it made in the whole of 2008 – an increase that has helped it move from having 1 per cent of the overall fee pool at the start of the financial crisis to 3 per cent today.In doing so, it has pivoted its entire business model: as of this year, the investment bank now generates more than half of its revenue in the US.“Having more than half of our business here in the US shows prospective employees that we are here for the long haul – that’s important to someone committing their future,” says Blair Fleming, head of RBC’s investment bank and capital markets in the US.To fuel the next phase of this growth, RBC has recently embarked on a hiring spree that is turning heads at some of the US’ largest banks. During the first half of 2014 it hired 19 managing directors into its investment bank and lost only 5, giving it a net gain of 14. Of the traditional Wall Street banks, only one had a net positive MD hiring rate – JPMorgan – while all the others declined, according to data from recruitment company Sheffield Haworth.“Part of the proposition is that when the financial crisis occurred, we were presented with the opportunity to build out our US business and we were able to grow more quickly and more profitably than we could have otherwise,” says Mr Fleming.RBC shares the advantage of many of its Canadian peers of having gone into the crisis with relatively little exposure to the worst hit parts of the financial system.
