But it was also quick to act when trouble hit, selling off its money-losing retail banking operation to PNC Financial in 2011.Mr Fleming, who took the reins of the US investment bank in 2009, says, only half jokingly, that when RBC was pitching for deal work before the financial crisis, they were often confused with Royal Bank of Scotland, the UK lender that expanded aggressively – both in the US and at home – only to be laid low by the onset of the crisis. Today, RBS is in the process of exiting a large part of its US operations, spinning off Citizens Bank through an initial public offering last month.“The ambition is to keep growing the market share but in a way that is stable,” says Mr Fleming. “We have learnt the lesson of other banks that have come in and tried to build too quickly – it doesn’t last.”He is also keen to steer away from the practice of buying out entire teams from rival banks. “We avoid it. If you bring in a whole team, it can create a them and us mentality and disenfranchise the staff.”When the financial crisis occurred, we were presented with the opportunity to build out our US business and . . . grow more quickly . . . than we could have otherwiseIn spite of the positive momentum, there is scepticism among rivals about RBC’s ability to marry rapid expansion with best practice.Earlier this year, the bank was rebuked by a Delaware judge who ruled that RBC had, in its desire to profit, failed to disclose conflicts of interest when advising ambulance operator Rural/Metro Corp on its sale to private equity buyer Warburg Pincus. RBC, which was also offering to fund Warburg’s acquisition, a practice known as staple financing, was accused of pushing for a quick sale rather than seeking a higher price.Also, although RBC has made inroads to the broader dealmaking market in the US, it still generates a disproportionate amount of its business from the energy and natural resources sector, reflecting its Canadian roots. Mr Fleming and his lieutenants are keen to grow the bank’s role in other sectors, but concede it will take time.Processed food deals may not be core to that endeavour, but having the pick of which party to back in any transaction is a luxury banks fight hard to preserve. In the end RBC chose to side with Tyson, the successful buyer of Hillshire.

Titular: Tyson to sell Brazil and Mexico poultry operations
Texto: Tyson Foods has agreed to sell its poultry businesses in Brazil and Mexico to rival JBS, the world’s largest meat processor, for $575m in cash.The move comes just over a month after Tyson beat JBS subsidiary Pilgrim’s Pride in a bidding war for Hillshire Brands, the packaged meat company. The Arkansas-based company said it would use the proceeds, along with the sale of shares, to pay down debt associated with its $8.6bn acquisition of Hillshire.“Although these are good businesses with great team members, we haven’t had the necessary scale to gain leading share positions in these markets,” said Donnie Smith, chief executive of Tyson Foods.JBS said the Mexican and Brazilian assets it is buying will boost revenues by about $1bn annually.It is paying $400m for the Mexican business and $175m for Tyson’s three processing units in the south of Brazil, it said.The deal comes amid a flurry of activity in the food sector, as conglomerates reshuffle their brands, producers seek to win back pricing power from a consolidated retail industry and global groups seek growth in new markets.It also marks a milestone in the long-running rivalry between Tyson and JBS, the Brazilian company that has spent billions on acquisitions over the past decade in order to overtake Tyson as the world’s largest meatpacker.Tyson, the largest US meat processor, said it will continue to serve Mexico with US-produced chickens and some poultry produced in the country through a co-packaging arrangement with Pilgrim’s Pride.While it is shrinking operations in Latin America, Tyson said it “intends to remain focused on growing its poultry operations in Asia”.Tyson also plans to focus more on the areas where Hillshire is a market leader: packaged and prepared foods, along with the breakfast category, which are important growth segments in the meat industry.The news came as Tyson reported net income of $260m, or 75 cents a share excluding one-time items, in the quarter ended June, up from $249m, or 68 cents a share excluding items, during the same period a year earlier. Sales rose 11 per cent to $9.68bn.Analysts had expected Tyson to report earnings of 78 cents a share and sales of $9.47bn.Tyson reported a $15m operating loss for its international business in the quarter, driven by weakness in Mexico, Brazil and China.Shares in Tyson rose 3 per cent to $40.56 by close of New York trading, while shares in JBS were up nearly 2 per cent.In May this year JBS, which is controlled by Brazil’s Batista family, announced plans to float its poultry and processed food unit in a bid to raise further cash for its global expansion plans.Additional reporting by Samantha Pearson in São Paulo

Titular: Constellation cheered by Modelo results
Texto: Constellation Brands was toasted by investors as the $5.3bn acquisition of beer maker Grupo Modelo, completed last year, showed further signs of paying off.Shares in the wine, beer and spirits company jumped 2 per cent to $90.45 on its results for the quarter, continuing an upward trend since Constellation acquired the Mexican business.Its market value has risen 76 per cent during the past year.A marketing campaign for its newly acquired beers, including Model Especial and Corona, had lured consumers as the summer began, the brewer said.Constellation raised its annual profit forecast to between $4.10 and $4.25 a share, up from an earlier estimate of $3.95 to $4.15.The group, which is based in New York, secured Modelo’s US business after regulators forced larger rival Anheuser-Busch InBev to offload it.AB InBev was seeking approval to buy the rest of Grupo Modelo.Sales more than doubled to $1.53bn in the quarter from a year earlier while profits followed a similar upward path, climbing to $215m.Ahead of the bank earnings season, shares in Bank of America rose 2 per cent to $15.85 after Deutsche Bank upgraded its target value from $16.50 to $18.Analyst Matthew O’Connor noted that shares in the lender were almost 10 per cent below recent highs after investors had priced in a “slew of disappointments”, including weaker first-quarter results than expect, an accounting error that halted capital deployment plans and the US Justice Department mortgage settlement.“These issues are well known at this point,” Mr O’Connor wrote.“[Earnings per share] power has an upward trajectory and if macro conditions improve, EPS and valuation should both benefit.”He concluded that there was less litigation risk for the bank, apart from remaining mortgage issues, than for some of its peers that face action over Libor manipulation, foreign exchange trading and money laundering scandals.Shares in Delta Air Lines fell 5 per cent to $38.24 after it reported lower growth than expected in passenger revenue per seat available.The measure increased 4.5 per cent in June, year on year, but was less than expected because of lower international yields.Domestic demand had been strong, Delta reported, but business demand to Latin America was lower because of the World CupShares in Tyson Foods rose 3 per cent to $38.96 on news that it had sealed its deal to acquire Hillshire Brands for $8.55bn after beating rival bidders.Tyson’s acquisition of Hillshire had been only a matter of time after a bidding war with Pilgrim’s Pride forced the price up to $63 a share – about 70 per cent higher than Hillshire’s value before the battle erupted.For the acquisition to happen, Hillshire had needed to extricate itself from a promise to buy Pinnacle Foods.Tyson disclosed on Wednesday that it had paid Pinnacle a $163m termination fee on behalf of Hillshire to shelve that deal.Shares in Hillshire were little changed while Pinnacle Foods was down 2 per cent to $31.48.Harley-Davidson fell 4 per cent to $67.80, after broker Raymond James downgraded the motorcycle company from “strong buy” to “market perform”.Overall, US equities remained on a modest upward march. The S&P 500 rose 0.1 per cent to 1,974.62. The Dow Jones Industrial Average edged 0.1 per cent upwards to 16,976.24 and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.02 per cent to 4,457.73.

Titular: Bush and Clinton pass the pork test
Subtitular: Much of today’s campaign-related sizzle is being generated by two old-line political brands
Texto: US politics and breakfast sausage have a good deal in common these days. In both realms, people are becoming pretty excited about familiar brands.I’ll start with the pork because that’s usually what we do when it comes to matters of governance in this country. Plus, it has been a big week in American meat. In a blockbuster deal, Tyson Foods, an Arkansas company that processes about a fifth of US beef, chicken and pork, agreed to buy Hillshire Brands, owner of the Jimmy Dean sausage brand, for nearly $8.6bn.Even if you are vegetarian, the Tyson transaction is noteworthy, since it is typical of our times. Big companies are in good shape, but the economy is not, so they are using their cash for acquisitions that offer opportunities for efficiencies or provide a modicum of diversification.It’s a cautious strategy as such things go, and led Tyson to one of our best-known food brands. Jimmy Dean breakfast sausages were made famous by their creator, a country star, who served as the folksier-than-thou television pitchman for his eponymous processed meat products for decades. He died four years ago aged 81.Still, betting on such an established name proved risky for Tyson because it did so with such zeal. Several Wall Street analysts say the company overpaid and investors have sent its shares lower in the days after the deal.It is a cautionary tale, which is particularly provocative because of the parallels in the US political scene as we gear up for the 2016 presidential election.Amid the same uncertainties, much of today’s campaign-related sizzle is being generated by two old-line brands as ubiquitous in our politics as Jimmy Dean sausages have been in our breakfast skillets. I speak of Bush and Clinton – names found on seven straight winning tickets in presidential elections before the emergence of Barack Obama in 2008 enabled Americans to change the channel, as it were.Jeb Bush, 61, seasoned by two terms as Florida governor, is a favourite of moderate Republicans seeking a less piquant alternative to such fiery competitors as Kentucky’s Rand Paul, Ted Cruz of Texas or the Jersey Shore’s Chris Christie.Hillary Clinton, 66, is staking out a similarly flavoured position on the Democratic side. She published a book this week about her time as secretary of state, which Slate’s John Dickerson described as a “low-salt, low-fat, low-calorie offering with vanilla pudding as the dessert”.The Bush and Clinton brands are sure things in the Jimmy Dean mould. They have been processed and market tested, making them particularly palatable for a number-crunching donor class that also trades in pork products, tech start-ups, fixed-income securities, commodities and all that jazz.The danger, of course, is that political brands like any others can lose their appeal. Former Tea party projectile Eric Cantor found as much this week when he was defeated in a Republican election in his Virginia district by an even more rightwing opponent and said he would like to leave his post as majority leader in the House of Representatives.The question facing the Bush and Clinton brands is whether their well-cultivated ambiguity will help or hurt. For all their renown, we know relatively little about what – if anything – Jeb Bush or Hillary Clinton have in mind for the US. Mr Bush is obviously trying to set himself apart from red-meat Republicans on immigration by saying that many of the people who come here illegally are engaging in “acts of love”. But if memory serves, all the Bush men perform this sort of kinder-gentler, compassionate-conservative number before they invade Iraq or nominate hardliners for the Supreme Court.The former secretary of state, meanwhile, offers the promise of a Clinton restoration, but that’s a slippery subject in its own way. Are we returning to the first Clinton term, when the president and his wife tried – and failed – to secure healthcare reform? Or the second, when Bill Clinton signed legislation that cleared the way for the creation of more complex banks and exempted credit default swaps from stricter regulation?It’s too bad we can’t ask the late Jimmy Dean for help on these matters because it would probably take a good sausage man to fully explain the Bush and Clinton political brands. As for now, they smell pretty good in the frying pan, but it’s hard to know exactly what’s inside these things.gary.silverman@ft.com

Titular: Tyson Foods slides after raising Hillshire bid
Subtitular: Premium offered by Tyson not seen benefiting short-term investors
Texto: Tyson Foods, the US meat producer caught in a bidding war earlier this year for Hillshire Brands, slid for a second day after the company lifted its offer to $8.55bn, a concern for analysts and investors who are sceptical of how it will generate returns on the deal if ultimately consummated.Tyson’s $63-a-share cash offer forced Pilgrim’s Pride to withdraw from the bidding, although Hillshire has yet to back the bid.Analysts at Credit Suisse said the 70 per cent premium offered by Tyson would create value for investors who have a “seven, ten, or twenty-year investment horizon”, although it will not benefit shorter-term investors.“Unfortunately, most investors don’t have the luxury of investing with such a long-term view,” analyst Robert Moskow said. “We believe Tyson stock will be dead money at best for the next 12 months as it copes with the hangover of paying such a big price.”Shares of Tyson fell 4 per cent to $36.07 by close of trading, taking its losses over the past three months to 7 per cent. Shares of Hillshire were unchanged at $61.97 while Pilgrim’s Pride were 2 per cent higher at $25.02.After rallying 15 per cent over the past month, shares in B/E Aerospace were felled by news the company had shelved plans to sell the company or one of its units in favour of separating into two businesses.The company said it would split into one company focused on manufacturing aircraft cabin interiors and another focused on distribution, logistics and technical services for the aerospace and energy services markets. Shares declined 5 per cent to $94.15.Shares of Chico’s, the womenswear chain, soared 8 per cent to $16.53 after the Financial Times reported the retailer is exploring a sale to private equity groups and has discussed a deal with potential suitors that could lead to one of the largest take-private transactions so far this year.The publicly traded retailer, which held a market value of $2.36bn before the report, has spoken to several private equity buyers in recent weeks, according to people familiar with the situation.eHealth, the private healthcare website exchange, was under pressure after brokerage Jefferies lowered its view on the company to ‘hold’ from ‘buy’, citing issues connecting to the federal government’s data hub.The hub allows a select group of private website exchanges to sell insurance policies listed on healthcare.gov to individuals, but those connection issues have hindered the business.“During our healthcare conference, CEO Lauer indicated discussions with the government to fix federal data hub connectivity hadn’t improved and that officials weren’t making it a high priority,” analyst David Styblo said.eHealth shares fell 13 per cent to $33.91.Facebook was among the top performing stocks on the benchmark S&P 500 on Tuesday after it poached David Marcus, the president of eBay’s payments division, PayPal, to lead its messaging products division.Once a pioneer, Facebook is trying to keep pace with the fast-changing way in which people communicate online. It has launched several standalone apps over the past year, including a rival to photo-sharing app Snapchat. Facebook climbed 5 per cent to $65.77.Shares in eBay fell 3 per cent to $48.25 following the announcement, and the departure of Mr Marcus caps a testing six months for the company.RadioShack shares continued a years-long tumble, falling 10 per cent to $1.38, after reporting another poor quarter in which like-for-like sales dropped 14 per cent.Overall sales for the quarter to May 3 dropped to $737m from $848m in the same quarter a year ago. The chain’s loss for the period ballooned to $98m from $28m.Like other electronic retailers who made their names and fortunes before the arrival of the internet, RadioShack has been beset by online competition.The Texas-based company is closing stores, revamping others and working with an incubator of technology start-ups in an effort to win back American consumers.Twitter was helped by another brokerage upgrade, as Wells Fargo added its name to a growing list of investment banks who believe the stock’s sharp decline since the year’s start represents a buying opportunity.“While we remain concerned about user growth and engagement, we believe Street expectations have declined substantially following two quarters of relatively modest user growth,” analyst Peter Stabler said.Mr Stabler lifted his rating to ‘market perform’ from ‘underperform’, sending shares 3 per cent higher to $35.37.Overall, equities coasted lower after four straight days of gains. The S&P 500 fell 0.02 per cent to 1,950.79 while the Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 0.02 per cent to 16,945.92. The technology-heavy Nasdaq Composite increased 0.04 per cent to 4,338.00.eric.platt@ft.comTwitter: @ericgplatt

Titular: Tyson wins bid battle for Hillshire Brands
Texto: Tyson Foods has knocked out rival poultry producer Pilgrim’s Pride in the bidding war for Hillshire Brands with what it called a “unilaterally binding” $8.55bn offer, bringing it a step closer to acquiring the maker of Ball Park hot dogs.Tyson’s $63-a-share offer topped the latest $7.7bn bid from Pilgrim’s, which on Monday said it would not increase its offer.Hillshire agreed to talks with both suitors last week. But the Chicago-based company said Monday its board had not approved the Tyson offer or changed its recommendation in favour of Hillshire’s planned acquisition of Pinnacle Foods, the frozen foods maker, which must be cancelled in order for the Tyson deal to proceed.“Hillshire Brands does not have the right to terminate the merger agreement with Pinnacle Foods on the basis of the Tyson Foods offer or enter into an agreement with Tyson Foods prior to its termination,” Hillshire said.But analysts said the company would likely face a shareholder revolt if it turned down the Tyson bid, which represents a nearly 70 per cent premium to Hillshire’s unaffected share price. Hillshire shares were up nearly 5 per cent, to $61.85, in New York trading, while Tyson shares were down nearly 5 per cent, to $38.23.The acquisition would give Tyson, the largest US chicken processor, a firmer foothold in the prepared and packaged foods market, an important growth segment in the meat industry, and give it a prime position in the breakfast category. Donnie Smith, Tyson chief executive, said the deal “would represent a defining moment for Tyson Foods”.Mr Smith told analysts on a conference call that while the transaction may seem rushed, Tyson had “been thinking a long time about Hillshire and how it can complement Tyson”.It comes amid a flurry of activity in the food sector, as companies seek to win back pricing power from a consolidated grocery business and global groups seek new international markets.May 2014: Global merger and acquisitions activity has just passed the $1tn mark – the first time the figure has been reached at this point of the year since 2007.It is also a victory for Tyson in its long-running rivalry with Pilgrim’s and its majority owner JBS, the Brazilian company that has spent the past decade making acquisitions in order to overtake Tyson as the world’s largest meatpacker.The offer caps a bidding war that began a month ago when Hillshire announced that it would buy Pinnacle for $6.6bn, a move that many saw as a means to head off a takeover.Two weeks later, Pilgrim’s offered $6.4bn for Hillshire so long as it cancelled the Pinnacle deal. Within 48 hours Tyson offered $6.8bn. Last week, Pilgrim’s raised its bid to $7.7bn.If the Hillshire board cancels the Pinnacle deal, it must pay that company a $163m termination fee. Tyson’s offer expires on December 12.Tyson said the transaction would be paid in cash and through a fully-committed bridge loan from Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan, which are advising the company along with Davis Polk & Wardwell. The company said it expected to rapidly pay down debt through the deal’s projected $300m in annual cost savings.

Titular: Tyson/Hillshire: Meatpacking district
Subtitular: Tyson wants to take a bite out of the market for prepared products
Texto: According to a recent Tyson Foods investor presentation, “a strong capital structure creates opportunities”. Its latest opportunity: winning the brief but intense bidding war for pork processor Hillshire Brands. Tyson’s $63 per share offer ($8.6bn in total) knocked out smaller rival Pilgrim’s Pride – which withdrew from the auction saying it is a “disciplined acquirer”.Tyson’s heft proved to be the winning edge. It commands an enterprise value of $15bn (versus Pilgrim’s $7bn). But its shares traded down 5 per cent on Monday, suggesting that shareholders are wondering if Tyson boss Donnie Smith chose the right opportunity.Tyson is a purveyor of protein. Its revenues are divided between beef (41 per cent), pork (15 per cent) and chicken (31 per cent). The diversity has paid off as commodity shocks in recent years have shifted the value proposition between meats. Poultry is now fashionable as strong grain harvests have lowered feed costs. Chicken has also benefited from rocketing beef prices– cattle supplies remain thin – as well as high pork prices brought on by diseased pigs. Tyson has taken out $1bn in costs from its vertically integrated chicken business since 2008. Its beef and pork businesses are not integrated in the same way and have managed to pass on higher input costs.Having mastered the commodity meat business, Hillshire presents the chance to get into more “prepared” meats. Hillshire’s operating margin of 9 per cent is double that of Tyson’s. The EV to earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation deal multiple is 11 times. However, that multiple includes $300m in cost savings, a thick slab, representing 40 per cent of Hillshire’s operating costs in the past 12 months. Tyson’s shares are up 200 per cent in the past five years. The best opportunity may be for Tyson shareholders to collect their gains.Email the Lex team in confidence at lex@ft.com

Titular: Casinos sink on Macau spin of wheel
Texto: US casino operators fell broadly as the latest gambling figures from Macau, the world’s gaming hub, fell short of Wall Street expectations.Overall gaming revenues rose 9.3 per cent from a year earlier to 32.4bn Macanese patacas, or $4.1bn, according to the latest report from the Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau.Analysts on average had expected a rise between 13 and 15 per cent.Since the year’s start, revenues have reached roughly $20.8bn, or 16 per cent higher than the year ago level.Analysts with Citigroup said much of the weakness in the sector – the Dow Jones US Gambling Index has fallen 13 per cent over the past three months – has been due to recent reports of “crackdowns on illegal use of Union Pay Cards, transit visas and junkets running away”, which they say are overblown.“Adding to pressure, in May the Macau government announced that a full smoking ban in the mass gaming areas will be implemented,” analyst Anil Daswani said.“Again, we believe these fears are overdone as the ban will not apply to premium mass or VIP.”Citi added the addition of new rooms would likely lift overall growth in the sector in the coming years.Wynn Resorts fell 4.49 per cent to close at $208.23, Las Vegas Sands dipped 2.57 per cent to $75.44 and MGM Resorts International declined almost 3 per cent to end the day at $25.83.Dollar General stuck to its profit forecast even as consumers spend more on lower-margin items at a US discount chain that has fared well since the financial crisis.The company, which is based in Tennessee, said it was generating lower profits from its sales as shoppers buy more “lower-margin consumables” such as tobacco and candy.While Dollar General stuck to a prediction that it will make between $3.45 and $3.55 a share in the current financial year, it cautioned “the volatility of the macroeconomic environment continues to pressure the consumer”.Overall, sales climbed almost 7 per cent to $4.52bn in the quarter to May 2. Net income rose to $222m from $220m.Shares in the company advanced 3.85 per cent to close at $56.39.Hillshire Brands, the US company behind Jimmy Dean sausages, said it will start talks with both Pilgrim’s Pride and Tyson Foods over the takeover bids that the companies have each made.Shares in Hillshire jumped about 9.5 per cent to close at $58.65 after Pilgrim’s Pride confirmed it had raised its offer from $45 a share to $55 a share in cash.Pilgrim’s Pride shares fell 2.24 per cent to $25.34 while Tyson declined just over 3 per cent to $42.07.Tyson Foods has an offer of $50 a share, or roughly $6.8bn, on the table.The fight for Hillshire, which itself is trying to buy rival food producer Pinnacle, comes as companies seek to wrestle pricing power from retailers, global groups seek growth in new markets and conglomerates reshuffle their brand portfolios.US carmakers advanced on Tuesday as General Motors, Ford and Chrysler all topped monthly sales expectations.Any reputational damage that General Motors has incurred because of its mass recall of cars has yet to reach showrooms in the US.Sales of its vehicles rose 12.6 per cent in May from a year earlier, almost double the tally that analysts had forecast.Although the figures echo the strong performance across the industry last month, they also underline that the decision by GM chief executive Mary Barra to recall more than 10m cars in the US has not put off consumers.Ford reported a 3 per cent rise in US sales in May. Ford shares rose 0.64 per cent to $16.55 while General Motors climbed 1.12 per cent to close at $35.25.Overall, US equity markets closed slightly lower. The benchmark S&P 500 fell 0.04 per cent to 1,924.24 while the Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped 0.13 per cent to 16,722.34. The technology-heavy Nasdaq Composite ended the day off 0.07 per cent at 4,234.08.eric.platt@ft.comTwitter: @ericgplatt

Titular: Hillshire agrees to hold talks with rival suitors
Texto: The bidding war over Hillshire Brands is heating up, with the packaged meat company agreeing to hold talks with its suitors after Pilgrim’s Pride raised its offer to $7.7bn, up $900m from rival poultry processor Tyson Foods’s bid.Pilgrim’s new offer, which includes debt, is equivalent to $55 a share and tops its original $6.4bn offer by $1.3bn. It represents a 49 per cent premium on Hillshire’s unaffected share price. Pilgrim’s made its first offer last Tuesday, followed two days later by Tyson, which offered $6.8bn for Chicago-based Hillshire.A person familiar with the offer said it was “a decisive, major step”, not an incremental offer. “The ball is not in Pilgrim’s court.”The new offer sent Hillshire shares soaring 9.5 per cent to $58.65 by the close of New York trading, and came as the company said it would “provide information” and conduct talks with both bidders.The $55 a share cash offer marks the latest salvo in the long-running rivalry between Tyson, the largest US meatpacker, and JBS, the majority owner of Pilgrim’s. JBS has spent the past decade making a series of acquisitions to overtake Tyson as the world’s largest meat company.The combined Hillshire and Pilgrim’s would generate more than $12bn in annual revenues, and join Colorado-based Pilgrim’s fresh and frozen chicken business with Hillshire’s focus on beef and pork, including Ball Park hot dogs.The bidding war comes amid a flurry of activity in the food industry, as global groups seek growth in new markets, conglomerates reshuffle their brands and producers seek to win back pricing power from retailers. Hillshire’s willingness to conduct talks with its suitors raises questions about whether its plans to acquire Pinnacle Foods, known for Vlasic pickles and Birds Eye frozen foods, will go through.Hillshire announced its $6.6bn acquisition of Pinnacle three weeks ago, though many questioned whether the merger, which lacked clear cost efficiencies, was meant to head off a potential takeover.Both Tyson and Pilgrim’s have said that they would only acquire Hillshire if it cancelled the Pinnacle transaction, incurring a $163m termination fee.The acquisition would help both Pilgrim’s and Tyson, which are traditionally known for fresh or frozen poultry, ramp up their offerings in packaged foods and breakfast, key segments.But analysts have warned that packaged meat companies do not generally offer much global growth opportunities.Pilgrim’s said its offer was not subject to any financing or contingencies and would result in more than $300m in annual cost savings.

Titular: Tyson offers $6.8bn for Hillshire Brands
Texto: Tyson Foods has injected itself into the deal frenzy gripping the US food industry with a $6.8bn bid for Hillshire Brands, an offer that came less than 48 hours after Pilgrim’s Pride launched a $6.4bn takeover.Both Tyson and Pilgrim’s are seeking to block Hillshire, the company behind Jimmy Dean sausages and Ball Park hot dogs, from going ahead with its planned $6.6bn acquisition of Pinnacle Foods, announced two weeks ago.If Hillshire swallows Pinnacle, a frozen foods maker, the enlarged business would be a less attractive and expensive target, according to analysts.Tyson’s $50 a share cash offer is also the latest jab in its long-running rivalry with Brazil-based JBS, which owns a majority stake in Pilgrim’s. JBS has spent the past decade making acquisitions in order to overtake Tyson as the world’s largest meatpacker.Donnie Smith, Tyson chief executive, said his offer, which was $5 a share higher than his rival’s, was “more certain than what can be attained in the near term by the company either on a standalone basis or in combination with any other food processing company”.Hillshire shares closed 17.7 per cent higher at $52.76, indicating investors expected still higher bids. Chicago-based Hillshire said in a statement it was reviewing the Tyson bid “in consultation with its independent financial and legal advisers”.A person familiar with Pilgrim’s offer said the company was considering its options. “Anything’s on the table,” the person said.Hillshire will incur a $163m termination fee if it drops Pinnacle, which did not respond to requests for comment.If Tyson succeeded in buying Hillshire it would create a company with more than $39bn in annual revenues. It would also give Tyson access to Hillshire’s strong breakfast business, an increasingly important meal for food companies.“We believe that the strength of Hillshire’s products in the breakfast category would allow Tyson to capture opportunities from shifting consumer trends in this attractive and fast-growing daypart where Tyson has little presence today,” Mr Smith said.Bob Goldin, of food consultancy Technomic, said the acquisition of Hillshire would help Pilgrim’s and Tyson, which are traditionally known for fresh or frozen poultry, break further into packaged foods, another key segment.“What it does for Tyson and/or Pilgrim’s is offer more of a stable profit stream,” he said.But he warned that packaged meat companies do not generally have the “global expansion capabilities” to justify their high prices. Pork loins tend to sell better than hot dogs in China, he said.May 2014: Global merger and acquisitions activity has just passed the $1tn mark - the first time the figure has been reached at this point of the year since 2007.Tyson shares had jumped nearly 8 per cent to $43.94 before closing at $43.25. Pilgrim’s shares closed 1.1 per cent lower at $25.09. Pinnacle shares were up 1 per cent to $31.68.Tyson said it had secured a fully committed bridge facility from Morgan Stanley, which it expected to be joined by JPMorgan. Both banks are advisers. The company said it was prepared to issue equity as financing.Shortly after news of the offer, JBS USA, parent company of Pilgrim’s, announced it had temporarily withdrawn an unrelated bond offering on which Morgan Stanley had been lead arranger.

Titular: Yum Brands shakes off bird flu fears
Texto: Yum Brands struck a bullish tone for 2014 even after the fast food group reported a 5 per cent drop in fourth-quarter earnings which showed food safety concerns continued to weigh on its China division.David Novak, chief executive, called 2013 a “challenging year” for the company behind the Pizza Hut, KFC and Taco Bell brands. However, he reaffirmed a previous forecast of double-digit earnings growth, sending shares up 4.22 per cent, to $68.95, in after-hours trading in New York.The Kentucky-based company reported net income of $321m, or 86 cents a share excluding one-time items, for the three months to December 28. That compared with $337m, or 83 cents a share excluding one-off items, during the same period a year earlier. Revenues fell 1 per cent, from $4.18bn to $4.15bn.Analysts had expected earnings of 80 cents a share on $4.26bn in sales.The news comes days after Shanghai began a three-month ban on live poultry sales and as Hong Kong launched a three-week ban on Chinese poultry and killed 20,000 birds after mainland Chinese imports tested positive for bird flu.Jonathan Blum, chief public affairs officer, said the company was “not seeing any impact nationally on our sales in China” from the fresh reports of avian flu.Food safety concerns and an avian flu outbreak early last year sent Yum’s China same-store sales plummeting. But the company went on a marketing offensive and was thought to be recovering when it reported positive sales growth in November and December.Same-store sales in China fell 4 per cent during the quarter, and fell 13 per cent for the full year.August 2013: The chief executive of Fonterra apologised to Chinese consumers for a food safety scare that threatened to damage the reputation of the world’s largest dairy exporter in one of its most important marketsThe company is China’s largest western restaurant group by sales and number of outlets, with more than 4,400 KFC restaurants alone. China contributes around half of Yum’s total revenues.Yum is not the only company being hit by bird flu concerns in China.On Friday Donnie Smith, chief executive of Tyson Foods, the largest US meat processor by sales, said the company would slow the pace of its China expansion as mainland demand for chicken continues to suffer.Mr Smith told analysts on a conference call that the company no longer expected to break even in China in the fiscal year ending in September. Because demand for chicken had not rebounded from the food safety and avian flu scares that began in late 2012, there was a “substantial oversupply of chicken”, he said.“Now, there are new concerns about avian influenza,” Mr Smith said. “Because of these factors, we decided to slow down on building more chicken farms beyond those currently planned for this fiscal year until market conditions improve.”Tyson ultimately plans to build 90 large chicken houses in China in order to supply its processing plants with quality-controlled poultry raised in sanitary conditions.

Titular: Beef: varied diet
Subtitular: A good thing meatpackers such as Tyson Foods and JBS also have exposure to chicken
Texto: Where’s the beef? Stampeding higher, as it happens. US cattle prices have risen to fresh highs at the start of 2014, building on a multiyear climb as the US herd has shrunk. The question for meatpackers such as Tyson Foods and Brazil’s JBS is whether they can pass on the higher prices in an environment where US consumers remain constrained.An annual USDA survey from January 2013 showed 89m head of cattle and calves, the lowest inventory since 1952. Ranchers have culled in response to lower demand – consumers are favouring chicken as a cheaper and healthier alternative – and elevated feed costs in recent years. The price of corn soared in 2012 when a severe drought hit the Midwest of the US.The 2013 corn crop was particularly good, and prices have fallen sharply, but it takes three to five years for cattle prices to adjust, according to JPMorgan. (Gestation alone is nine months for cows.) The timeline for chicken, by contrast, is a matter of months. This, and the greater demand, mean the outlook for chicken is much better than for beef. Any increases to the herd also mean an initial decline in supply as ranchers hold some lucky cows back from the slaughterhouse for breeding.Good thing, then, for shareholders of Tyson and JBS that each has exposure to chicken, too, which should help offset some of the pressure on beef. At Tyson beef contributed 42 per cent of sales in 2013, but with margins at about half those of chicken, operating income from beef was 22 per cent of the total against 47 per cent for chicken. JBS, which controls Pilgrim’s Pride, can also steer towards its Brazil beef business where exports should benefit from the real’s declines. Sometimes investors want pure plays, but the dynamics in animal protein show diversification can have meaty benefits.Email the Lex team in confidence at lex@ft.com

Titular: Meat producers: talking turkey
Subtitular: US poultry producers are clucking, and for good reason
Texto: Too soon? Some Americans may be too full to think about chicken, pork and beef – and don’t even mention turkey. But US poultry producers are clucking, and for good reason. Last year, they endured a severe drought in the Midwestern part of the country. The price of corn – a key component of feed – spiked above $8 a bushel in 2012. It has since fallen back to half that, and the US will harvest a record crop this autumn.Lower grain costs factored into the positive outlook at Hormel Foods, which this week said it expected earnings per share in 2014 to rise as much as 16 per cent. Hormel processes turkey and pork and manufactures packaged foods such as Spam and Dinty Moore stew. Now is a good time to be in the turkey business. As input costs have fallen, so have production levels (242m birds in 2013 versus 254m, according to the USDA). That bodes well for pricing. But it is not all good news down on the farm. The outlook for hogs is less clear – a virus has created uncertainty. Still, in 2013, Hormel also bought Skippy brand peanut butter, which it expects will lift earnings per share by a mid-single digit percentage this fiscal year.Investors are already reaping gains. Shares of Hormel have risen 50 per cent over the past year as prospects improved. At $45, the stock trades at 20 times next year’s earnings. Fellow meat producers Tyson Foods (chicken, beef and pork) and Pilgrim’s Pride (chicken), which have also rallied sharply, trade at 12 and 9 times, respectively. These two are more pure commodity plays than Hormel, which is a diversified seller of branded products. That justifies some premium. Hormel’s earnings multiple was also higher than the median – 17 times – over the past 10 years. Here, too, expansion is warranted given growth expectations and the addition of Skippy.But at these prices, Hormel is starting to look a bit stuffed.Email the Lex team in confidence at lex@ft.com

Titular: Tyson Foods: still tasty
Subtitular: Meat processor could benefit from concerns about quality
Texto: Returns on Tyson Foods haven’t exactly been chicken feed. The stock is up more than 50 per cent so far this year and nearly 100 per cent during the past 12 months. Tyson, along with other meat processors, was under pressure during last year’s drought in the US, which raised the price of the grain these companies feed chickens, cattle and hogs. Now grain prices are falling in anticipation of a bumper crop. Last week, for example, only 2 per cent of the Midwest region was in drought, compared with 74 per cent a year ago, according to the US Drought Monitor.On Monday, Tyson’s shares rallied to all-time highs following quarterly earnings that beat expectations. For the quarter to June 29, Tyson’s net profit more than tripled. The year-ago quarter included a charge for the early repayment of debt, but underlying profitability also rose. The chicken segment, which contributes about half of operating profits, had record operating income in the quarter with margins increasing to 7 per cent from 5.6 per cent a year ago as higher sales and prices offset rising input costs. Demand for chicken, as a cheaper and healthier alternative to beef and pork, is up and Tyson has moved away from fixed contracts in recent years to be able to adjust its prices based on its grain costs.With the favourable weather this year, the company should have the advantage of lower input costs. And, Tyson is expanding internationally, including in China where it stands to benefit from concerns about quality. Shuanghui International this year agreed to buy pork producer Smithfield Foods. Investors should be aware that the Tyson family, through a special class of stock, controls about 70 per cent of voting rights. At $30, Tyson trades at 11 times forward earnings versus an average of 10 since 2010 and a high of 14. That isn’t exactly chicken feed either, but might still be tasty.Email the Lex team in confidence at lex@ft.com

Titular: Tyson shares unable to buoy US indices
Texto: Strong earnings from Tyson Foods sent its shares higher while US equity markets ticked down from the record highs set in the first two trading days of August.The US meat producer overcame high feed prices to beat expectations on earnings and revenue. Shares in Tyson rose 4.1 per cent to $29.69 and have risen more than 53 per cent this year.Tyson’s ability to raise prices to offset increasing business costs has helped the company to beat analysts’ estimates.Berkshire Hathaway also issued a positive report that sent shares higher, beating earnings per share estimates. Warren Buffett’s conglomerate delivered net earnings of $4.54bn in the second quarter on a strong showing by its rail and financial derivatives businesses.Berkshire’s A shares rose 0.5 per cent to $177,300.But positive earnings were not enough to continue the record-setting run from US equity markets. The S&P 500 ticked down 0.2 per cent to 1,707.14, with eight of the 10 major sectors closing in negative territory.The Russell 2000 index of small-capitalisation companies shook off weakness from the broader market, touching fresh record highs. The index was up 0.2 per cent to 1,061.46.The S&P 500 rally in 2013 has been so consistent that analysts are beginning to assert that the question is not if the market will suffer a decline, but when. The benchmark index has been positive in six out of seven months this year.While long-term prospects for US equities remain bright, there is some concern in the short term that investors will begin to lock in profits, said Sam Stovall, chief equity strategist for S&P Capital IQ, in a note.“From strength comes suspicion that things look too good to be true, and that a new, and possibly deeper, stock market decline looms,” he said. “Since no one really knows when the rally will end, it may be wise to lock in the gains of some high flyers and reinvest in those that have yet to leave the ground. You may just have a shorter distance to fall.”S&P Capital IQ has a 12-month target for the S&P 500 of 1,780.JC Penney shares fell 3.2 per cent to $13.82 despite announcing the hiring of Debra Berman, a Kraft Foods executive, as its new head of marketing. The position had been vacant for the past 14 months.Shares in the retailer have struggled in 2012 as the company attempts to recover from a decline in sales following an attempt by its former chief executive – Apple veteran Ron Johnson – to reinvent the company.The company is hoping a return to its former discount ways will put it back on track, but analysts have been worried about the rate at which the company is spending its cash reserves.The Dow Jones Industrial Average was off 0.3 per cent to 15,612.13, but the Nasdaq finished slightly higher at 3,692.95.The tech-heavy index was helped by a 3 per cent gain from Facebook. Piper Jaffray boosted its price target for the stock to $46 from $38, which adds more momentum to the social network’s recent rally.Shares of Facebook are up about 50 per cent since reporting earnings, particularly mobile ad revenue, that cheered investors.

Titular: South American harvest hits grain prices
Texto: Agricultural markets retreated on Tuesday, with corn falling for the eighth session in a row as rising expectations for South American crops relieved worries about tight supplies in the northern hemisphere.Corn for March delivery was below $7 a bushel for the first time since January 11, trading 1.1 per cent lower at $6.94¾ by midday on the Chicago Board of Trade.CBOT March soyabeans weakened 0.8 per cent to $14.20½ and March wheat dropped 1.7 per cent to $7.29.Selling has snowballed since the US Department of Agriculture raised estimates of global corn, soyabean and wheat stocks in a report late last week. South America is expected to produce record corn and soyabean harvests just as stocks in the US run low.Brazil will overtake the drought-plagued US as the world’s largest corn exporter this year, with export prices at the port of Paranagua consistently cheaper than corn along the US Gulf of Mexico, USDA said.“The current crop is also expected to be a bumper harvest,” the agency’s foreign agricultural service said in a circular last week. =Cheaper grain and oilseeds will bring relief to the food industry, especially livestock and poultry companies. Tyson Foods, a top US chicken and beef producer, anticipates feed costs will rise by $600m this year.“At these price levels, this is an attractive buying opportunity for some end users” of feed, said Erin FitzPatrick, commodity analyst at Rabobank.The sharp retreat of grain prices has caught many speculative traders by surprise. Money managers have been building net bullish positions in corn since early January, according to Commodity Futures Trading Commission data, suggesting some are now being flushed out of the futures market.Analysts warn that prices of grain futures for imminent delivery could nevertheless jump as Brazil’s transportation network strains to move a huge crop to the world.Archer Daniels Midland and Bunge, two of the largest international merchants in the region, have reassured investors they had expanded storage silos and invested in port facilities to handle massive exports, but some in the market worry about a short-term squeeze until South American supplies reach international markets.Oil World, a German oilseed market consultant, described a “long line of ships waiting for soyabeans at Brazilian ports” and “unusually small farmer selling” in Argentina, partly because they are waiting for a peso devaluation that would increase the local profitability of export sales.“Any delays in transporting the commodities to the ports can, in turn, delay the expected global replenishment,” Chris Narayanan, agricultural analyst at Société Générale, said in a report. He added that while this could temporarily keep prices high, bullish surprises from South America were becoming unlikely.

Titular: Meat producers face record feed prices
Texto: Meat producers are braced for a sharp hit to profits after the price of a key ingredient for fattening chickens and pigs hit an all-time high as a result of the intense heatwave in the US farming belt.Soyabean meal, crushed from oilseed and mixed with corn to make animal feed, on Thursday exceeded the record set during the 2007-08 food crisis. Benchmark CBOT July soyameal futures rose to a record $475 per short ton, up 4.6 per cent.Other futures markets also surged late in the session. Corn was at its highest in more than a year, with benchmark CBOT July corn reaching $7.76¾ a bushel, up 8.1 per cent on the day. The December contract, against which much of the coming harvest will be priced, hit a peak of $7.13 a bushel, up more than 37 per cent over the last three weeks.Soyabeans rose to within reach of a record set in July 2008, hitting a session peak of $16.44½ a bushel, up 4.6 per cent.The jump in prices will hurt chicken processors such as Tyson Foods, Sanderson Farms and Pilgrim’s Pride, which is controlled by Brazil’s JBS. Poultry eat more than 40 per cent of the meal crushed from US soyabeans, according to Bill Roenigk, chief economist at the National Chicken Council.Meal prices soared along with broader grain markets as drought and temperatures of more than 100F (38C) were forecast to continue in US corn belt states such as Illinois, Indiana and Iowa, threatening crop yields.Mike Cockrell, chief financial officer of Sanderson Farms of Mississippi, said feed made up 55 per cent of the company’s cost of goods sold. It had locked in soyameal costs only through to the end of July.“At the end of the day, chickens eat corn and soyabean meal. There are no viable substitutes.” he said. “So we and others in our industry will have no choice but to pay a higher cost to feed our chickens. If history proves a reasonable guide, high-priced grain means high-priced meat at some point in the future”.“If you know how to do a rain dance, I encourage you to do so,” said Mr Cockrell.Tyson Foods told analysts in May that it had bought soyameal “four to five weeks out”, suggesting it could be vulnerable. The company declined to comment.The rally in corn and soyabean prices also dragged wheat prices higher. CBOT July wheat rose 5.2 per cent to $8.22½ a bushel, the highest since May 2011, when the market was still wrestling with the impact of an export ban in Russia.Mr Roenigk said many chicken companies had bought into early projections of large crops in the US and refrained from locking in feed costs. “Every day that goes by when it doesn’t rain in the Midwest, companies are realising that they should have bought. But plenty of them didn’t,” he said.

Titular: Brazil looks to beef up its business
Texto: From his office on an outer ring-road of São Paulo, Wesley Mendonça Batista, chief executive of JBS, is looking to steer Brazil’s biggest meatpacker by revenue deeper into emerging markets.Since he and his brother Joesly launched a series of mergers and acquisitions in the US and Australia that created the world’s largest meat exporter, times have been tough.Shrinking US, Australian and European cow herds, depressed economic conditions and declining beef consumption for health reasons in advanced economies has been hard on margins.“We can grow in a double-digit way our revenue but we need to be more focused, to look to areas in which we can grow more profitably,” Mr Batista says, citing growth markets such as the Middle East, north Africa, Russia and the former Soviet Union.However, any expansion into these markets will not go uncontested. Mr Batista and rival meatpackers in Brazil, such as Minerva and Marfrig, or in the US, such as Tyson Foods, have a newcomer to contend with – India.Led by Alanna & Sons, a Dubai-based exporter of Indian beef, mainly water buffalo, Indian companies have gained share in the global beef industry quickly, albeit at the discount end of the market.Indian beef exports are expected to reach 1.525m tonnes this year from only 609m tonnes in 2009, outstripping world leaders Australia and Brazil, according to US Department of Agriculture figures.This has come in spite of stagnation in overall global production of beef and veal, which is down 2.4 per cent from its peak in 2007, before the financial crisis, the USDA says.“Although you have the middle classes consuming more beef in developing countries like Brazil, you have developed economies such as the EU and the US with declining rates of beef consumption,” says Gabriel Vaz de Lima, an analyst with Barclays in São Paulo, who recently rated JBS “underweight” because of negative meatpacking spreads in the US.In the US, a brutal drought in Texas last year resulted in the smallest herd the US has had since 1952, although meatier cows partially offset the decline in population.US cattle futures hit records earlier this year, while domestic beef demand has taken a hit from the weak economy, changing consumer tastes and a controversy over additives used in the production of meat trimmings used in ground beef, known pejoratively as “pink slime”.Cargill, one of four large US beef processors, reported weaker meat results in the beginning of the year because of what it called a “cyclical downturn in North American beef”, while Tyson Foods broke even in beef in its latest quarter amid what it called “extremely challenging market conditions”.“Domestic demand for beef did not match what packers were paying on cattle prices,” says Bob Wilson, analyst at HedgersEdge, an agricultural market research service.With the US now in high summer “grilling season”, domestic consumption is expected to pick up. Operating profits for US meat packers have rebounded to about $25 a head, from a loss of $112 a head as recently as April, says HedgersEdge.US beef processors are turning to overseas markets to fill the gap, with export volumes last year breaking records, according to the US Meat Export Federation.International producers, such as JBS, are fortunate to have had the booming Brazilian market to offset problems in the US. Brazilian ranchers are expanding their herds, resulting in greater supply for meatpackers.“We are seeing the opposite of what is happening in the US – cattle prices have fallen 5-7 per cent, there is higher availability of supply,” says Mr Vaz de Lima of Barclays.While Brazilian exporters such as JBS will increasingly encounter products from Indian exporters in emerging markets, producers on the subcontinent will face their own challenges.They will need to move up the value chain to command higher prices and they will continually need to reassure a religiously sensitive domestic Hindu population that no cow meat is being exported. Several Indian states ban the slaughter of cows, which are considered sacred for Hindus.“There is no exact data on the amount of [cow] beef being slaughtered and sold as people fear violent attacks from Hindus,” says a Mumbai-based executive of a food processing group. But he added it could be as much as 5 per cent.Prakash Javadekar, a senior member of India’s Hindu nationalist party, the BJP, says violence against people slaughtering cows was not justifiable. But it would be difficult to restrain those who believed cows were holy. “This is our religion. People should respect this,” says Mr Javadekar.

Titular: ‘Pink slime’ fears eat into Tyson
Texto: The “pink slime” controversy that has plagued the US beef industry took a bite out of Tyson Foods’ second-quarter earnings.The biggest US meat processor by sales said on Monday that its beef sales volume fell 10.7 per cent year-on-year in the second quarter and that its beef business recorded a $1m operating loss.“The unwanted controversy over lean, finely textured beef temporarily destroyed demand for ground beef, and beef in general, virtually overnight,” James Lochner, Tyson’s chief operating officer, said on a conference call with analysts.The beef industry has been under pressure this year over a public outcry against an additive known as “lean, finely textured beef”. The additive, known pejoratively as “pink slime”, is often found in ground beef and is made from beef trimmings that are processed with ammonia to make them lean and free of bacteria.The beef industry was dealt another blow last month when US agriculture officials confirmed a new case of mad cow disease in California. The discovery sent cattle prices down sharply because of fears that global beef demand would wane.Tyson said on Monday that cattle prices had rebounded but that the company had experienced “extreme margin compression” in March and early April.Backlash against the so-called “pink slime” filling caused Beef Products Inc to suspend production in three of its plants. Mr Lochner said at a conference in March that the negative publicity was hitting ground beef demand and that BPI's move would create a shortfall in beef supply.“It’s a very unfortunate thing because it was a very safe, very wholesome, very nutritious product that will now be not available to the consuming public,” Mr Lochner said.In spite of pressure on its beef business, Tyson’s net income rose 6.4 per cent year-on-year to $166m, or 44 cents a share. Sales rose 2.5 per cent to $8.2bn.High feed costs have been putting pressure on Tyson to raise prices, but the beef controversy has made this increasingly difficult.However, Tyson said that it expected a decline in industry production this year to make it easier for the company to raise chicken prices. Tyson made an operating profit of $145m in its chicken business and $115m from pork.The results were better than Wall Street analysts expected, and Tyson’s shares closed up 3.3 per cent at $18.63.

Titular: US stocks steady after European elections
Texto: US equities edged higher on Monday as market watchers said investors had already priced in expectations that pro-austerity leaders in Europe would be defeated over the weekend.Meanwhile, shares in the bailed-out insurer AIG lost 3 per cent to $31.84 after the US Treasury said on Sunday that it will offer 63 per cent of its stake in the company to the public at $30.50 a share. AIG will purchase $2bn worth of the latest offering which is valued at $5bn.The S&P 500 moved fractionally higher to 1,369.58 as stocks held steady despite some fears that election results in France and Greece would add further instability to markets.The benchmark US index is looking to recover its losses from last week when it dropped 2.4 per cent, as shares declined heavily on Friday ahead of the European elections.The Vix Index, known as Wall Street’s “fear gauge”, fell 1.6 per cent to 18.85. Barry Knapp, chief US equity strategist at Barclays, said: “The elections were as expected and will only serve to bring attention to the broader issue of slowing economic growth, not due to austerity. The culprit is excess debt and the resultant deleveraging in the banking system.”He added: “The current debate about growth or austerity is a red herring; the markets are not going to fund additional spending by governments that already spend at a rate of 50 per cent of gross domestic product.”The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.1 per cent to 2,957.76.Apple, the heaviest weighted stock on the Nasdaq, moved 0.8 per cent higher to $569.48 as the company’s shares look to recover from last week’s decline of 6.4 per cent.Shares in Cognizant Technology Solutions were among the leading decliners as the outsourcing company said its full-year sales and earnings would come in below expectations.Cognizant lost 19.2 per cent to $56.31 as it said demand had cooled for its services heading into the second-quarter.AT&T, the largest US telecommunications group by revenues, announced on Monday that it would enter the fast-growing home automation market with a portfolio of new services, including remote energy and water controls.The company, which is seeking to expand its services offering beyond its traditional range, will join rival Verizon, which launched its own home-monitoring business in October.Shares in AT&T were 0.4 per cent higher to $33. Verizon shares gained 0.7 per cent to $40.53 on the day.Yahoo, the internet search and media company, moved 1.3 per cent higher to $15.35 as it sought to dealwith calls for its recently appointed chief executive to resign. Dissident investors have urged Yahoo’s board to fire Scott Thompson for misinformation about his educational qualifications on his personal résumé.B-class shares in Berkshire Hathaway, the holding company led by Warren Buffett, rose 1.9 per cent to $82.47 following its annual meeting where the chief executive said the size of recent acquisitions paled in comparison to those his successor would need to make. Mr Buffett, who still has not publicly named his successor, also described his diagnosis of prostate cancer as a “non-event”.Tyson Foods, the US meat producer, was among the leading gainers after it said second-quarter earnings rose despite climbing beef prices.The company reported first-quarter net income of $166m, or 44 cents a share, up from $156m over the same period a year ago. Shares in Tyson gained 3.3 per cent to $18.62.The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.2 per cent to 13,008.53. Earthmoving equipment maker Caterpillar lost 1.3 per cent to $97.19.Ahead of its second-quarter earnings report on Tuesday, Walt Disney Co jumped 2.1 per cent to $43.82. The entertainment group’s latest film, The Avengers, generated over $200m in sales in its opening weekend. The US opening lifted the worldwide total for the film to $642m after only 12 days on release.The S&P 500 financial index was leading the major sectors, rising 0.7 per cent. Bank of America was ahead of its rivals and added 2.8 per cent to $7.94, but in recent weeks the company has moved well below its highest point for the year at roughly $10.The S&P 500 energy index was 0.2 per cent lower. Miner Alpha Natural Resources lost 1.7 per cent to $14.21.

Titular: Correction: A long-time suitor for Pringles
Texto: ● Tyson Foods was not a long-time suitor for Pringles as incorrectly stated in an article on February 16.

Titular: Buyers fight $1.1bn Innkeepers hotel deal
Texto: Cerberus, the private equity group, and Chatham Lodging Trust are trying to walk away from their $1.1bn deal to buy 64 hotels from bankrupt chain Innkeepers, arguing that the business had undergone a so-called “material adverse change”, enabling them to terminate their contract.The pair, which in May were selected as the winning bidders for Innkeepers’ hotels, said that they had terminated their agreement to buy the hotels on Friday. They pointed to language in the deal’s terms that enabled them to walk away should a “condition, change or development” threaten to have a “material adverse effect” on the Innkeepers business.People familiar with the matter said that the Innkeepers properties had been performing steadily in the past few weeks and saw no deterioration that would merit the buyers’ claiming a “material adverse effect” from the weakness in the economy or volatility in the markets.The US courts have taken a dim view in the past when buyers have attempted to use MAC or MAE clauses to stop deals.In 2001, the Delaware Chancery Court said that Tyson could not use a MAC to get out of its deal to buy beef processor IBP. The chancellor, Leo Strine, argued that a “short term hiccup in earnings should not suffice” in justifying the occurrence of a MAC and that a longer-term test was appropriate.The attempt by Hexion, the industrial company owned by Apollo, to use a MAC to walk away from its 2007 deal to buy Huntsman in the midst of the financial crisis was also unsuccessful.Cerberus and Chatham made the decision to terminate their agreement with Innkeepers’ jointly, people familiar with the matter said. However, they had not provided any further information as to the basis for their claiming a material adverse change, others added.The $1.125bn that Cerberus and Chatham offered to pay for the properties included the assumption of $725m in mortgage debt on 45 of the properties. Cerberus agreed to provide most of the cash needed for the deal, with Chatham set to take a 9 per cent stake in the pair’s joint venture and contributing about $37m.Chatham separately agreed to purchase five hotels from Innkeepers for $195m, a deal that closed in July.Innkeepers on Monday had yet to respond to the decision by Cerberus and Chatham. The auction for the 64 hotels earlier this year also attracted interest from other parties, including Five Mile Capital Partners, an alternative investment company with about $2bn in assets under management.

Titular: Bank and energy stocks lead US declines
Texto: US stocks took a steep dive on Monday as traders reacted late in the session to the US credit rating downgrade by Standard & Poor’s, with the benchmark S&P experiencing its biggest one-day fall since December 2008.The benchmark S&P 500 slumped 6.7 per cent to 1,119.68, its lowest level in 11 months, with banks on the index targeted by traders fearful of the perceived weakness of the US economy.The volume of shares traded was also high, as the verdict on the downgrade – which signalled a lack of confidence in the US economy – was handed down in dramatic fashion.It followed heavy losses in the previous week, the worst for US stocks in two years, as fears over the strength of the recovery came to the fore.Smaller company shares fared the worst on Monday as the Nasdaq Composite index sunk 6.9 per cent to 2,357.69. The Russell 2000 index of small and mid-cap groups dropped 7.9 per cent.The main indices had been bolstered briefly on Friday by indications that the European Central Bank would buy Italian and Spanish debt.That continued to shield stocks from a more precipitous fall early in the session before a late sell-off after Barack Obama, US president, made an afternoon speech on the credit downgrade that traders felt lacked conviction.Bank of America  was the biggest faller on the S&P 500, plummeting 20.1 per cent to $6.75 after American International Group filed a lawsuit against the bank for loses incurred on mortgage-backed securities.Citigroup also dropped 15.8 per cent to $28.16, while Genworth Financial sank 16.8 per cent to $5.64.Energy stocks again also saw steep declines, dropping 3.3 per cent in the opening minutes of trading as oil and gas prices fell. Stocks directly tied to the economy were also targeted in the sell-off.Alpha Natural Resources, the coal producer, continued its downward slide after second-quarter losses last week, slumping a further 18.5 per cent to $26.35.Valero Energy, the pertroleum company, was also down 11.6 per cent to $18.31, while US Steel lost 13.1 per cent to $28.84.Sunoco, another petroleum company that last week admitted it had just finished an “abysmal” quarter, fell a further 11.6 per cent to $30.08.But a new record for gold saw shares of Newmont Mining, a producer of the precious metal, lose just 0.5 per cent to $54.13 a share. Newmont shares were among the few to post gains last week, adding 0.2 per cent.Large-cap shares were not targeted as hard, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 5.6 per cent to 10,809.85.It was heavily weighed by the steep drop in shares of Bank of America, but strategists at UBS and Morgan Stanley recommended shifts into large-cap growth shares as a defensive move.Tyson Foods, the only S&P 500 company reporting earnings, was down 3.7 per cent at $15.71 despite the meat and poultry seller topped earnings expectations for the quarter, earning 46 cents a share versus forecasts of 39 cents.Dean Foods, which unlike Tyson primarily uses agricultural commodities as inputs, saw its shares drop 7.3 per cent to $8.40, among the worst performers in the S&P 500.Despite the day’s losses, strategists were broadly arguing that the rating agency’s downgrade was not a strong direct catalyst for share prices, which globally enjoyed their worst week since the 2008 financial crisis amid slowing economic growth in big economies and worries about European sovereign debt.“Today’s tape is going to look worse than it should,” said Nicholas Bohnsack, sector strategist at Strategas, a research firm. “Did S&P really tell us something we didn’t know?“Corporates are the new sovereigns with so much cash on their balance sheets. That kind of goes out the window for a day or two here as we sort out where Treasuries will be priced but I don’t think this will have an impact on companies.”Bruce Bittles, chief market strategist at Baird, suggested that there could be a case for a turnround, given that investor sentiment as measured by the American Association of Individual Investors showed a drop in the percentage of retail investors surveyed calling themselves “bears” – marking a bottom for the widely followed indicator.“The equity markets are extremely oversold and investor fear is beginning to creep in,” he said.However, he warned: “Until the momentum is interrupted by two sessions where upside volume overwhelms downside volume by a ratio of at least 10 to one, investors should be defensive.”Elsewhere, Priceline.com, the discount travel website, among the best market performers of the past two years, fell back after big jumps last week as its earnings and travel bookings came in ahead of expectations. Its stock dropped 4.3 per cent to $505.00.Sprint Nextel, the mobile phone company, extended its recent slump, falling 15.9 per cent to $3.13, in spite of announcing that it would launch its new 4G model, priced at less than $100, later this month.

Titular: Rising grain costs restrict Tyson’s growth
Texto: Tyson Foods, the largest US meat processor by revenues, blamed weak economic growth, high levels of unemployment and the rising costs of feeding chickens for a lacklustre third quarter.Donnie Smith, chief executive of Tyson, said that fragile macroeconomic conditions combined with a swollen supply of chicken and elevated corn prices meant that its chicken business could suffer a loss in the current quarter.“The fact that we remained profitable in such a difficult environment demonstrates how much our chicken business has improved in the past three years,” Mr Smith said. “There appears to be improvement in market fundamentals on the horizon but the next few months will be very challenging.”Net income at Tyson fell by 22 per cent from a year ago to $188m, or 51 cents a share. Sales rose 10.9 per cent year on year to $8.2bn.The results exceeded estimates by Wall Street analysts and Tyson’s shares rose 1.23 per cent to $16.51 in midday trading on Monday.Pork and beef sales propped up Tyson in the third quarter, thanks to greater international demand for those products. But the chicken business remained soft, and Tyson said that it would need to raise prices to keep up with rising grain costs.“We’re focused on pricing because the current situation is simply unsustainable,” Mr Smith said in a conference call with analysts. “We believe we’re adjusting to a new paradigm.”Operating profit in the chicken business was just $28m, while operating profit for beef and pork was $140m and $124m respectively.Corn and soyabean prices have increased by 10 cents a pound in the past two years. Mr Smith said that besides price increases, Tyson would look to diversify its chicken business and would be reducing the weight of its eight-pound “big bird” chickens because the costs of feeding them have become exorbitant.Analysts at Morgan Stanley forecast that it will be a “long road” back to profitability in the chicken business and that Tyson should raise prices gradually.According to Fitch, the rating agency, excess supply and weak pricing will continue to put the chicken industry under pressure.“High grain costs will continue to cause margin pressure in the near term but recent pullbacks in production could signal capitulation for the chicken producers,” said Carla Norfleet Taylor, director at Fitch.Tyson said that while the US market continued to face headwinds, it was stepping up its efforts to invest in Brazil, China and Mexico.

Titular: Sealed Air wraps up Diversey deal
Subtitular: The acquisition provides Sealed Air with relatively cheap entry into a new area
Texto: Journalists seeking cheap puns about a bubble in mergers and acquisitions and spurious claims of diversification were handed a gift with Sealed Air’s agreement to purchase cleaning products company Diversey on Wednesday. Just as obvious, the maker of Bubble Wrap mentioned that the transaction would be accretive in the first year and it trotted out venn diagrams to highlight overlapping customers such as Walmart, Coca-Cola and Tyson Foods. But, in this era of ultra-low interest rates, nearly any deal with a substantial cash component should boost earnings per share initially and it is hardly surprising that two large companies would have customers in common in food manufacturing and retail.The acquisition does provide Sealed Air with relatively cheap entry into a new and not wholly-unrelated area. Though synergies are modest at just $50m per annum or just over 1 per cent of the $4.3bn purchase price, the adjusted trailing multiple of enterprise value to earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and ammortisation is 8.7 times, about three-quarters of competitors Ecolab and Procter & Gamble. Diversey, which mainly sells hygiene products to large buyers, is less profitable than both, but margins have been on a clear upward trend under the guidance of penny-pinching private equity shareholders.Will Diversey do even better under new ownership or has it already been put in as flattering a condition as possible? That is unclear and Sealed Air’s own spotty record of shareholder wealth generation – essentially zero since the beginning of 2000 – does not inspire. Management would hardly admit that it wants Diversey for growth’s sake or because bankers were dangling cheap financing, but it is hard to avoid that impression. Much like Sealed Air’s most famous product though, the deal only provides a firm underpinning as long as bubbles stay inflated.E-mail the Lex team in confidence at lex@ft.com

Titular: Upbeat jobs figures lift Wall Street
Texto: Cisco Systems lost ground after issuing a profit warning, while the wider markets edged higher after broadly positive economic data and firmer commodity prices helped to lift investor sentiment.Shares in Cisco fell 4.8 per cent to $16.93 after the world’s largest producer of networking gear by revenues announced that its sales and profits in the current quarter would come in below expectations.The company also reported that its net income had fallen 18 per cent in its last quarter to $1.8bn, or 42 cents a share. This was broadly in line with expectations.News of the profit warning weighed on related technology stocks. Motorola Mobility fell 1.1 per cent to $24.98 while Harrislost 1.4 per cent to $48.29. The S&P technology equipment sector was down 0.7 per cent, although in the broader tech sector most stocks were up.Looking at the wider markets, the S&P 500 index closed up 0.5 per cent to 1,348.65, paring some of the 1.1 per cent losses in the previous session, with sentiment helped by upbeat employment data.Figures from the Labor Department showed that 44,000 fewer Americans applied for unemployment insurance last week.The number of new claims fell to 434,000, which was a bigger drop than had been expected and was the steepest fall since February 2010.It also reversed much of the sharp increase in claims in the previous week. But other data in the session were less positive, showing that the higher oil and food costs were hitting retail spending and lifting producer prices.The 0.5 per cent rise in retail sales in April and the 0.8 per cent rise in inflation were both slightly worse than the markets had been expecting.Still, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 0.5 per cent to 12,696.14 while the Nasdaq Composite added 0.6 per cent to 2,863.04.The energy sectors were again lower in the session, as traders remained uneasy following the recent volatility in the oil markets.Within the energy sector Murphy Oil fell 1.3 per cent to $66.63 while ConocoPhillips declined 1.4 per cent to $71.53. The broader S&P energy sector closed down only 0.1 per cent, however, after the oil priced edged a little higher. The S&P energy sector has fallen 7.2 per cent this month.Consumer staples and consumer discretionary stocks saw some of the biggest gains in a possible sign that some stocks are beginning to benefit from the recent drop in oil prices.Among the stocks to gain in these sectors, Tyson Foods was up 4.6 per cent to $18.84 while Mead Johnson added 2.1 per cent to $67.72. Best Buy rose 4.1 per cent to $31.69.The S&P consumer discretionary index was up 0.9 per cent and the consumer stable index added 1.3 per cent.The financial sector was one of the worst performing of the session, led by Goldman Sachs. Shares in the investment bank were down 3.5 per cent to $142.1 after pair of analyst notes downgraded the stock, warning investors that Goldman could still face charges from the US Justice Department for its behaviour during the financial crisis.Citigroup fell 1.2 per cent to $42.42, adding to the 5 per cent losses already this week after putting into effect a one-for-10 reverse stock split on Monday. The move reduced the number of outstanding shares of Citigroup’s common stock from about 29bn to 2.9bn.The S&P financial index was down 0.1, recovering from sharper losses earlier in the session as the afternoon continued.Elsewhere, shares in First Solar rose 6.3 per cent to $132.07, the best performing stock on the S&P 500 index, after the maker of thin-film solar modules received letters indicating support from the US Energy Department for three projects in California.Shares in Symantec added 5.2 per cent to $20.42 after the maker of security software reported fourth-quarter adjusted earnings of 38 cents a share, exceeding the average analyst estimate by 2 cents.VeriSign, the company best known for the management of internet domain names, was up 3.2 per cent to $36.68 after saying that it had resolved a lawsuit.Clearwire, a wireless broadband provider, fell 15.6 per cent to $3.99 after Intel said that it would sell 10m shares in the company.Elsewhere on Wall Street, shares in Kohl’s added 3.9 per cent to $55.68 after the retailer reported a 6 per cent rise in first-quarter profit and raised its earnings forecast for the year.

Titular: Wall St gains muted by eurozone debt fears
Texto: Dollar Thrifty Automotive surged after Hertz Global offered to buy the car rental company, while the wider markets advanced after deal activity and a rise in commodities outweighed concerns over the financial health of the eurozone.Dollar Thrifty bounced 13.8 per cent to $79.27 after Hertz made a $2.2bn offer for its smaller rival.The offer is a 24 per cent premium over a rival offer made by Avis Budget last September, and is 17 per cent higher than the 60-day average share price.The move comes eight months after Hertz supposedly bowed out of a battle to buy Dollar Thrifty, saying it would not seek to match a higher offer by Avis. Shares in Hertz were down 1 per cent to $16.68 while Avis gained 0.3 per cent to $18.47.In other deal action, Alkermes said it would merge with a drug technology unit of Elan, the Irish drugmaker, in a cash and stock deal valued at $960m. Shares in Alkermes rose 5 per cent to $15.19.This assorted deal activity helped encourage sentiment across Wall Street, but the biggest gains came from the energy and material sectors as commodity prices rebounded.In the energy sector, Baker Hughes rose 3.4 per cent to $71.65 while Marathon Oil added 5.3 per cent to $52.19.
